## Non-IFRS Measures

This Offering Memorandum includes certain financial measures which are not accounting
measures within the scope of IFRS, and may not be permitted to appear on the face of primary
financial statements or footnotes thereto and may not be permitted to be included in filings
under the U.S. Securities Act. The following are the primary non-IFRS financial measures that
are used in this offering memorandum:

- Adjusted EBITDA, which we define as EBITDA adjusted for (i) non-recurring headquarter
operating expenses (including redundancy payments and other related personnel costs),
(ii) non-recurring business unit expenses, and (iii) other ‘‘one off’’ items or non-recurring
gains and losses (including gains and losses realized from the sale of parking spaces to local
residents and gains and losses realized on the sale and acquisition of parking facilities and
equity stakes in new subsidiaries). Starting from January 1, 2019, Adjusted EBITDA includes
the impact of the application of IFRS 16;

- Adjusted EBITDA by business line, which we define as EBITDA for the relevant business line
_adjusted for (i) reallocation of overhead costs and non-recurring headquarter operating_
expenses, (ii) non-recurring business unit expenses (including redundancy payments and other
related personnel costs) and (iii) other ‘‘one-off’’ items or non-recurring gains and losses
(including gains and losses realized from the sale of parking spaces to local residents and
gains and losses realized on the sale and acquisition of parking facilities);

- Adjusted EBITDA Margin, which we define as Adjusted EBITDA divided by Adjusted Revenue;

- Adjusted Revenue, which we define as revenues plus other operating income less other
non-recurring revenues less other ‘‘one off’’ items or non-recurring gains and losses (including
gains and losses realized from the sale of parking spaces to local residents and gains and
losses realized on the sale of parking facilities);

- Capital expenditure, which we define as our payments through investments less our
collections through divestments. We divide our capital expenditure in two categories:
maintenance capital expenditure and expansionary capital expenditure. We define
maintenance capital as capital expenditure that relate to car park contract maintenance
requirements (mainly recurring maintenance works and repairs on car park facilities to ensure
they remain fully operational and compliant) prior to termination of the concessions to
operate such car parks but excludes the initial investment made under such contract.
Expansionary capital expenditure are further divide into: (i) renewal and growth capital
expenditure that relate to on-street investments which are required in concessions near to
their maturity and new contracts added to the portfolio, namely a concession acquisition or
an investment made in newly awarded contracts and (ii) M&A capital expenditure that relate
to new contracts added to the portfolio where we have acquired the share capital of the
company and not the asset itself.

- EBITDA, which we define as operating result excluding amortization and depreciation,
provisions and losses of unrecoverable credits and impairment and result through disposal of
fixed assets. Starting from January 1, 2019, EBITDA includes the impact of the application of
IFRS 16;

- EBITDA Margin, which we define as EBITDA divided by the sum of revenues and other
operating income;

- Free Cash Flow, which we define as Adjusted EBITDA less maintenance capital expenditure,
changes in working capital, cash taxes, non-cash items and non-current items. Non-current
items include one-off costs related to severance payments, advisor costs, one-off contractual

xv


-----

compensations and dividends received. Non-cash items comprise concession fee payments
registered according to International Financial Reporting Interpretations Committee 12
‘‘Service Concession Arrangement’’ (‘‘IFRIC 12’’) and IFRS 16;

- Free Cash Flow Conversion, which we define as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA;

- Gross debt, which we define as the non-current portion of bonds issued, bank borrowings,
leasing and other debt and the current portion of bonds issued and bank borrowings,
including accrued interest and excluding unamortized debt issue costs;

- Gross profit, which we define as Adjusted Revenue less Changes in inventories, Cost of sales,
Payroll, Other operating expenses excluding Other non-recurring changes in inventories,
Other non-recurring personnel costs and Other non-recurring expenses;

- Gross recourse debt, which we define as Gross debt excluding the non-current portion of
bonds issued, bank borrowings, leasing and other debt and the current portion of bonds
issued and bank borrowings of the Non-Recourse Entities;

- Gross non-recourse debt, which we define as the non-current portion of bonds issued, bank
borrowings, leasing and other debt and the current portion of bonds issued and bank
borrowings of the Non-Recourse Entities, including accrued interest and excluding
unamortized debt issue costs;

- Like-for-like revenues, which we define as revenues and other operating income adjusted to
eliminate any new concessions and any concessions that expired or were terminated during
the periods being compared.

- Net debt, which we define as Gross debt less cash and cash equivalents;

- Net recourse debt, which we define as Gross recourse debt less Recourse cash and cash
equivalents;

- Net non-recourse debt, which we define as Gross non-recourse debt less Non-recourse cash
and cash equivalents;

- Pro forma EBITDA, which we define as Adjusted EBITDA adjusted for terminated contracts
and new contracts as well as overheads savings;

- Recourse cash and cash equivalents, which we define as Cash and cash equivalents held by all
members of the Group excluding the Non-Recourse Entities;

- Non-recourse cash and cash equivalents, which we define as Cash and cash equivalents held
by the Non-Recourse Entities;

- Recourse Adjusted EBITDA, which we define as Adjusted EBITDA excluding Adjusted EBITDA
generated by the Non-Recourse Entities;

- Non-recourse Adjusted EBITDA, which we define as Adjusted EBITDA generated by the
Non-Recourse Entities; and

- Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our concessions, which we define as the average
period of time remaining on our concessions and contracts, weighted by the contribution
each concession has made to our Adjusted EBITDA.

See ‘‘Summary—Summary Financial, Operating and Other Information’’ and ‘‘Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation’’ for further_
information as to the calculation of these non-IFRS financial measures.

The non-IFRS measures presented in this Offering Memorandum may not be comparable to
other similarly titled measures of other companies. The EBITDA measures presented in this
offering memorandum differ from the definition of ‘‘Consolidated EBITDA’’ set forth under the

xvi


-----

caption ‘‘Description of Notes—Certain Definitions.’’ By eliminating potential differences
between periods or companies caused by factors such as depreciation and amortization
methods, financing and capital structures and taxation positions or regimes, we believe these
non-IFRS financial measures can provide a useful additional basis for comparing the current
performance of the underlying operations being evaluated. For these reasons, we believe these
non-IFRS financial measures and similar measures are regularly used by the investment
community as a means of comparing companies in our industry.

Our management also uses the non-IFRS financial measures described above to assess our
operating and financial performance and to make decisions about allocating resources in our
business. For example, management monitors the Weighted Average Remaining Duration for
our concessions in order to evaluate future cash flow variability and any associated risk.

None of the non-IFRS financial measures presented herein are a measurement of performance
under IFRS and they should not be considered in isolation or construed as a substitute for
(a) operating profit or profit for the period as a measure of our operating performance,
(b) cash flow from operating, investment and financing activities as a measure of our ability to
meet our cash needs or (c) any other measures of performance or liquidity.

The non-IFRS financial measures presented herein have limitations as analytical tools, including
the following:

- they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures,
contractual commitments or working capital;

- they do not reflect the significant interest expense or the cash requirements necessary to
service interest or principal payments on our debts;

- although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated
and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future, and the non-IFRS financial
measures do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such
replacements;

- some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating the relevant non-IFRS financial
measures reflect cash payments that were made, or will in the future be made;

- other companies in our industry may calculate the non-IFRS financial measures presented
herein differently than we do, which limits their usefulness as a comparative measure; and

- they remove the results of impairments and disposals of fixed assets which may also occur in
future periods.

Certain amounts and percentages included in this offering memorandum have been rounded.
Accordingly, in certain instances, the sum of the numbers in a column of a table may not
exactly equal the total figure for that column.

The financial information included in this offering memorandum is not intended to comply
with the applicable accounting requirements of the U.S. Securities Act and the related rules
and regulations of the SEC which would apply if the Notes were being registered with the SEC.

The Bloomberg Composite Rate is a ‘‘best market’’ calculation, in which, at any point in time,
the bid rate is equal to the highest bid rate of all contributing bank indications and the ask
rate is set to the lowest ask rate offered by these banks. The Bloomberg Composite Rate is a
mid-value rate between the applied highest bid rate and the lowest ask rate. The rates may
differ from the actual rates used in the preparation of the consolidated financial statements
and other financial information appearing in this offering memorandum. None of the Issuer,
the Guarantors or the Initial Purchasers represent that the U.S. dollar amounts referred to
below could be or could have been converted into euro at any particular rate indicated or any

actually represent U.S. dollar amounts or that these amounts could have been converted into
U.S. dollars at any particular rate, if at all.

The average rate for a year means the average of the Bloomberg Composite Rates on the last
business day of each month during a year. The average rate for a month, or for any shorter
period, means the average of the daily Bloomberg Composite Rates during that month, or
shorter period, as the case may be.

## Overview

We are one of the leading concessionaires and operators of parking infrastructure in the
Iberian Peninsula, as measured by number of parking spaces and revenues. We mainly operate
underground car parks (‘‘off-street’’), as well as some parking areas on city streets (‘‘on-street’’)
under concessions and surface rights agreements from public authorities. As of September 30,
2019, our portfolio comprised 403 concession contracts in 145 municipalities, under which we
manage over 436,920 parking spaces, including 33,366 resident spaces, primarily in Spain and
Portugal, and marginally in Andorra, Turkey and the UK. For the twelve months ended
September 30, 2019, our revenues were e197.3 million, our Adjusted Revenue was
e196.4 million, our Adjusted EBITDA was e90.6 million and we had an Adjusted EBITDA Margin
of 46.1%. Our operations in Spain and Portugal, respectively, represented 70.7% and 25.4% of
our Adjusted Revenue, 68.2% and 28.9% of our gross profits and 82.9% and 13.9% of our
parking spaces for the twelve months ended September 30, 2019. Our off-street concession
business and on-street concession business generated 56.5% and 35.5% of our Adjusted
Revenue, respectively, and 83.9% and 16.5% of our Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, for the
twelve months ended September 30, 2019.

We have served the Iberian market since the late 1960s. We believe this has given us a ‘‘first
mover’’ advantage, whereby we have continually secured long-term concessions and built a
portfolio of prime parking locations in Spain and Portugal, including in city centers, airports
and other high density traffic areas, such as hospitals and business districts. Due to a variety of
physical, regulatory and other constraints such as cost of space, we believe that there is limited
opportunity to develop alternative parking options in many of these prime areas, allowing us
to benefit from captive demand with limited competition. Due to an overall lack of available
land in major cities within our geographical focus, and an overall urbanization trend in the
current macroeconomic climate, we do not expect this competitive advantage to diminish in
the foreseeable future.

We generate revenues under three business lines:

- Off-street concessions. Our off-street concession business primarily comprises long-term
concessions, with contract lengths generally ranging from 20 to 50 years, granted by
municipalities to develop and operate parking facilities, primarily underground and multistory, and generated 56.5% of our Adjusted Revenue (e111.0 million) and 83.9% of our
Adjusted EBITDA (e76.0 million), and had an Adjusted EBITDA Margin of 68.5%, for the
twelve months ended September 30, 2019. Under these contracts, we are generally required
to invest in the construction of a new parking facility (a ‘‘green field’’ concession) or make an
upfront payment to the municipality for an existing parking facility (a ‘‘brown field’’
concession). We operate each parking facility on a long-term basis and generate our fees
based on tariffs charged to car park users, as set out in the relevant concession or surface
rights agreement, which typically increase each year in line with inflation. We generally
retain all fees generated from operating the relevant parking facility and are responsible for
all expenses relating to operating and maintaining the parking facility during the term of

1


-----

the concession. With respect to ‘‘brown field’’ concessions, we may pay an annual concession
fee to the municipality, an upfront fee or a combination of both. In addition, we sell a
limited number of parking spaces to local residents, receiving a monthly fee for the
rendering of maintenance services, as an ancillary activity in connection with the
development of some parking facilities. As of September 30, 2019, we had 285 off-street
concession contracts (including 78 resident contracts) under which we manage approximately
120,003 parking spaces. The Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our off-street
concessions was approximately 25 years as of September 30, 2019.

- On-street concessions. Our on-street concession business comprises concessions, with contract
lengths generally ranging from five to 20 years, granted by municipalities to manage metercontrolled on-street parking, and generated 35.5% of our Adjusted Revenue (e69.7 million)
and 16.5% of our Adjusted EBITDA (e15.0 million), and had an Adjusted EBITDA Margin of
21.5%, during the twelve months ended September 30, 2019. For these types of contracts,
we typically receive fixed fees that are inflation-indexed and which cover the yearly
amortized amount of our initial investment and operating costs and reasonable rate of
return. In a number of concessions, the contract also includes a variable incentive element
(which may be based on a percentage of the collected meter receipts, the number of parking
spaces or certain other indicators) to align the concessionaire’s objectives with optimizing
revenue collection. As of September 30, 2019, we had 114 on-street concession contracts
(including seven contracts exclusively dedicated to tow-away services) under which we
manage approximately 230,966 parking spaces. We have a long-standing presence in many
cities and a successful relationship with many municipalities which we believe provides us
with a competitive advantage in securing new off-street business. The Weighted Average
Remaining Duration of our on-street concessions was approximately five years as of
September 30, 2019.

- Off-street contract management. Our off-street contract management business involves
contracts to manage parking facilities on behalf of public authorities, primarily airports, as
well as a limited number of private entities. Our off-street contract management business
generated 8.0% of our Adjusted Revenue (e15.7 million) and did not affect our Adjusted
EBITDA in a meaningful way in the twelve months ended September 30, 2019. As of
September 30, 2019, we had four off-street management contracts. Under these contracts,
we operate and manage parking facilities with approximately 85,951 parking spaces on
behalf of third parties in exchange for a fixed fee. Although it is a relatively small part of
our overall business, our off-street contract management business line allows us to gain
expertise in managing complex operations, as well as to improve our access to municipalities
and build local market knowledge.

## Strengths

We believe that we have several competitive advantages in the car park sector in Iberia,
including our long-term contract revenues, diversified business profile, assets with low demand
risk and market leadership. As a result of these strengths, together with the stable regulatory
environment and favorable industry dynamics, our business benefits from a high level of
stability and recurring cash flows.

**_Uniquely positioned for growth on the back of Iberia’s favorable macroeconomic trends_**
The macroeconomic environment in Spain and Portugal, our largest geographic markets in
terms of revenues, has continued to improve. The car park industry has recently been growing
in Iberia, mainly driven by this factor as well as urbanization and an increase in the number of
cars. The profitability of the sector is generally improving, supported by scale efficiencies, the
implementation of cost savings programs and the utilization of innovative industry technology
(including digitalization), among other factors. See ‘‘Industry.’’ We believe that we are well
positioned to benefit from the continued improvement in the economic environment in Iberia
resulting in organic growth opportunities for us. The economic growth in Iberia may also lead

3


-----

to consolidation opportunities that provide room for further non-organic growth. We believe
that improvements in our business activity and revenues, along with a sustained cost-base, in
connection with such economic improvement, together with our various cost efficiency
initiatives, will have a positive effect on our EBITDA.

During the period from 2016 to 2018, we benefitted from the good macroeconomic landscape
in Iberia and were able to increase our Like-for-like revenues on a CAGR basis at a higher rate
than the CAGR of GDP in Iberia over the same period.

**_Leading car park concessionaire in Iberia benefitting from scale and high barriers to market_**
**_entry_**
We are one of the leading car park concessionaires in the Iberian parking infrastructure
concessions market both by revenue and total number of parking spaces and were the leading
car park operator in Portugal in terms of revenue, and the leading car park operator in Spain
by number of spaces, for the year ended December 31, 2018. As of September 30, 2019, we
managed 362,294 parking spaces in Spain (including 33,366 resident spaces), 60,678 in Portugal,
4,075 in Turkey, 8,500 in the UK and 1,373 in Andorra. We had approximately 25.0 million car
parking transactions in the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, based on the number of
payments made across all our car parks. Our size and growth have allowed us to achieve
significant economies of scale, and the scope of our operations, combined with the various cost
management measures we have implemented, have allowed us to maintain our Adjusted
EBITDA levels. For example, our centralized control room system controls and manages a
substantial majority of our off-street concessions business’ parking facilities from a remote
location, which has allowed us to improve our cash flow and reduce operating expenses,
headcount and personnel costs (we reduced the number of operators per car park by more
than half) without impacting our service quality and customer satisfaction levels. This is a key
driver for efficiency gains and margin improvements, particularly in the off-street segment,
allowing for more competitive pricing when bidding for new contracts and placing us in a
strong position for additional growth. In addition, our mobile maintenance personnel are
responsible for the maintenance of several car parks within a defined geographic area, which
reduces personnel expenses and standby time. This has allowed us to reallocate personnel to
perform certain functions previously outsourced, thereby reducing our reliance on third-party
service providers. Our economies of scale enable us to be a consolidation platform for smaller
Iberian parking operations, and allow us to undertake valuable new concessions and
acquisitions of smaller players. For example, when we acquired Boulevard in August 2019 we
integrated the company into our centralized control room system to reduce the number of
staff on site, ensured maintenance works were performed by dedicated local teams and
arranged for management services relating to human resources, tax or accounting, to be
conducted by centralized management teams. In addition, through our experienced

4


-----

management team and our long-standing reputation in the industry, we have been able to
develop and maintain important relationships with the various municipalities with which we do
business, thereby reducing our dependence on any single local authority or region.

We believe the upfront cost and difficulty in obtaining planning permission to build new high
density car parks in city centers, together with the favorable regulatory regime that applies to
concession agreements in Spain and Portugal as discussed under ‘‘—Stable regulatory
_environment with downside protection’’ below, as well as the scale required to operate car_
parks efficiently present significant barriers to entry in the car park industry. The stringent
regulatory framework governing parking concessions in Iberia reduces the risk of new
competitors entering the market. For example, due to the terms and lengths of concession
contracts (the average weighted life for off-street concessions is approximately 25 years as of
September 30, 2019), competitors can be locked-out of the off-street concessions business for
long periods of time. In addition, our size provides us with the scale required to operate a car
park portfolio efficiently. For example, our scale enables us to share resources among our car
parks including maintenance and supervisory staff, as well as management resources in respect
of accounting, marketing, human resources, insurance and tax matters. The number of our
locations also gives us a commercial advantage as we are able to anticipate customer needs
across multiple locations. In addition, the high initial investment required to produce efficient
IT resources is beyond the reach of smaller competitors. Between January 1, 2016 and
December 31, 2018, we invested an average of e1.5 million per annum in IT resources. Unlike
smaller operators, we can price into our bids the efficiencies that we can generate through our
portfolio, and thus offer more attractive terms to municipalities. Also, as there is a lack of
available land in the major city centers of Iberia, there are limited opportunities to construct
new car parks, and our scale provides us with numerous consolidation and expansion
opportunities, which many smaller competitors are unable to take advantage of.

**_High degree of diversification_**
Our business benefits from a portfolio which is highly diversified in terms of the following:
number of contracts, number of municipality clients and types of parking services we deliver.
We are also diversified through our three business lines, each of which has different risk
profiles and capital requirements, but with similar operational and managerial requirements.
As of September 30, 2019, we had 403 contracts, comprising 285 off-street concession contracts
(including 78 resident contracts), 114 on-street concession contracts (including seven contracts
exclusively dedicated to tow-away services) and 4 off-street management contracts. Our
off-street concession business line is further diversified in terms of location, municipality, end
user and type of contract (business district, hospitals, shopping areas and tourism). We believe
our limited reliance on any single contract is a significant factor in diversifying our source of
revenues and therefore reduces our cash flow volatility. While our ten largest off-street car
parks represented 20.2% of our total gross profit for the twelve months ended September 30,
2019, our largest car park represented less than 2.7% of our total gross profit during the same
period. We believe our diversified business portfolio differentiates us from other infrastructure
companies, who typically rely on a smaller number of larger contracts or concessions, with a
greater concentration of risk. We are highly selective as to our management contracts and we
only provide such services to the extent that they comply with certain margin and profitability
criteria.

**_Strategically located assets with attractive concessions and limited demand risk_**
We believe that our infrastructure portfolio is well invested. Our on-street concession and
off-street contract management businesses have low demand risk because we are generally
paid a fixed fee for the services we provide, regardless of occupancy of the car park. Although
our off-street concession business is subject to demand risk and fluctuations in volumes, we
believe the prime locations of our concessions will continue attracting car park users and
ensuring stable utilization levels given our car parks are located in high traffic areas at or

5


-----

within close proximity to city centers. Our business was created as a result of the acquisition of
the two historical leaders in the parking concessions market in Spain and Portugal, each with
prime concessions already in place. As a result, we were able to construct car parks in strategic
locations, including Playa de la Concha in San Sebasti´an and Cam ˜oes in Lisbon, and take
advantage of the existing concessions which were located within close proximity to city centers
and in high traffic areas. Therefore, we believe that we enjoy a prime position in the relevant
local area with respect to a significant proportion of our parking facilities. Moreover, the high
density of city centers together with planning regulations make the approval process for
‘‘green field’’ concessions difficult, effectively limiting the supply of parking spaces in a given
area. Additionally, many of our concessions in strategic locations have a long remaining life,
such as Cam ˜oes, Lisbon (32 years, 340 car park spaces), Playa de la Concha, San Sebasti´an
(39 years, 655 rotation spaces plus 619 resident spaces), Joan de Borb ´o, Barcelona (20 years,
617 rotation spaces plus 14 resident spaces), Restauradores, Lisbon (28 years, 545 car park
spaces) and Boulevard, San Sebasti´an (27 years, 381 rotation car park spaces and 630 resident
spaces), in each case as of September 30, 2019. The prime positions of our car parks and the
difficulty in building new car parks helps to reduce the demand risk in our off-street concession
business.

**_Stable regulatory environment with downside protection_**
The regulatory framework governing off-street and on-street parking concessions in Spain and
Portugal affords certain protections to the concessionaire. We and other car park
concessionaires that operate in Iberia have historically benefitted from a ‘‘rebalancing’’ clause
under the relevant concession legislation in Spain and Portugal, which may also apply to
Portuguese public surface rights agreements. Under certain circumstances, a change in the
balance of the economic terms and conditions of the concession that is adverse to the
concessionaire will trigger a right of the concessionaire to seek compensation or a
‘‘rebalancing’’ mechanism, which typically results in either an extension of the concession
period, an increase in tariffs payable by users, or sometimes an increase in the number of
parking spaces managed by the concessionaire, depending on the circumstances. This
regulatory environment has proven to be stable and predictable since the implementation of
the concession system more than 50 years ago and in the past, we have been successful in
relying on such protective legislation to seek additional compensation. Additionally, the
municipalities granting concessions have an interest in the success of public car parks since they
are a source of income for the municipality and the operation of car parks satisfies a public
need.

**_Highly stable business with limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements_**
For the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, 83.9% of our Adjusted EBITDA was
generated by our off-street concessions business, which had a Weighted Average Remaining
Duration of approximately 25 years. Between January 1, 2016 and September 30, 2019, we
have achieved a consistently high Replacement Rate across the business of 121%, including a
Replacement Rate our off-street concessions of approximately 189%. Our off-street concessions
business also benefits from regulated tariffs linked to inflation. Accordingly, we benefit from a
high level of recurring business and long-term visibility of cash flows, and we believe the longterm nature of our portfolio is matched by few other infrastructure companies in Spain and
Portugal. The most significant contracts in the off-street portfolio are public concession
agreements, with none or limited rent payments, which is not the case of a typical lease
contract more common in other European countries.

For the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, 16.5% of our Adjusted EBITDA was
generated by our on-street concessions business. We have achieved a Replacement Rate of
approximately 73% between January 1, 2016 and September 30, 2019, with respect to our
on-street concessions business. In addition, we also won a number of our competitors’ contracts
and, in some instances, we have successfully renewed our on-street concessions business despite

our superior technical competence, including the implementation of state of the art revenue

Our business model shares all the key features of infrastructure companies, such as long-term
cash flow visibility, resilient revenue generation, long-term concessions and a favorable and
stable regulatory environment with certain protections for the concessionaire in case of
regulatory or administrative change. However, unlike some other infrastructure companies
(including those operating toll roads), our car parks, once operational, require relatively low
levels of maintenance capital expenditure. Our limited maintenance capital expenditures are a
result of our scale and preventive maintenance measures and low operating intensity. Our
average maintenance capital expenditure during the years ended December 31, 2016 to 2018
was approximately e2.2 million per annum and mainly related to the requirements of our car
park contracts, including recurring maintenance works and repairs on our car park facilities to
ensure that they remain fully operational and compliant. As a result, we believe we are
well-positioned to benefit from returns on these investments. We expect to adjust our capital
expenditure plan to ensure that our technology systems are up-to-date with new technological
developments.

We benefit from attractive working capital dynamics with low levels of credit risk with respect
to our off-street concession business, since such revenues are collected from users when they
exit the car park. Our current business does not require significant investment in working
capital. For example, our off-street concessions business line generates negative working capital
because our revenues are generally collected when earned and our costs are paid according to
standard payment terms as agreed in each of our contracts. However, our on-street and
contract management businesses have higher working capital requirements as they are more
dependent on the payment terms from contracts with public bodies. In addition, our credit risk
with respect to our on-street concessions business is primarily with the municipalities rather
than private third parties. As a result of our low maintenance capital expenditures and working
capital requirements, we have achieved significant Free Cash Flow Conversion ratios of 63.9%
and 83.1% for the year ended December 31, 2018 and the twelve months ended September 30,
2019, respectively.

Any larger capital expenditures are primarily related to the expansion of our business,
including new acquisitions and grants of new contracts and concessions. We are constantly
securing new contracts and concessions as existing contracts and concessions expire. These are

## Strategy

Our key strategies are the following:

**_Maintain focus on growing revenue and improving EBITDA and cash flows_**
We will continue to implement measures designed to increase our revenues and thus enhance
our EBITDA and cash flows. Generally, under our concession agreements, we are subject to
limitations with respect to the maximum tariff that we can charge users of our parking
facilities. As a result, we have the flexibility to structure our pricing policy as we deem fit so
long as we do not exceed the maximum tariffs set forth in the concession agreement. Our
pricing policy varies on a case by case basis, and we may use any or all of the following pricing
mechanics in order to maximize demand and volumes: (i) season tickets, whereby we can offer
a range of different products to fit our customers’ specific needs (for example, offering specific
time slots on specific days or for specific periods of time), which can help to increase volumes
during those times of the day when rotation is less intensive, as well as have a positive impact
on our working capital as a result of receiving payments in advance, (ii) different tariff
structures, whereby tariffs will differ, for example, based on the time of day or the day of the
week, and (iii) long-dated sales, whereby we can expand our product and service offering by
developing special offers and promotions designed in partnership with third parties, such as
travel agencies in connection with holiday packages or special events.

We also seek to increase revenue and volumes within our off-street concessions business
parking facilities through increased deployment of car park signage and other forms of
advertising in city centers and other high traffic areas in which our car parks are located. In
addition, we anticipate that revenues from our large parking facilities opened in the past three
years will increase over the coming years as they are currently in the ‘‘ramp up’’ phase. Within
our on-street concession business, we seek to continue improving our revenue collection
through the implementation of best practices, such as our integrated platform for payment
(Telpark) and visual car enforcement in order to increase revenues collected for the relevant
municipality, which will thereby increase the level of variable incentive compensation we
receive under such concession. Moreover, we intend to continue to implement technological
improvements to achieve greater efficiency, which will allow us to more efficiently manage the
parking areas covered by our on-street concessions business and increase the number of
parking spaces covered per employee. For example, we plan on increasing the number of car
parks, both from our existing portfolio and new acquisitions that will be connected to our
centralized control room in order to reduce fixed costs.

9


-----

**_Maintain our disciplined and high operational efficiency_**
We will continue to focus on managing our business in a cost-efficient manner by using the
latest industry technologies and improving customer service. We will also continue to work
with car manufacturers to implement new technology systems. In the past, we have invested in
and installed several user-friendly IT applications to enhance the customer experience at our car
parks including electronic payment devices such as Via Verde, license plate recognition systems
and mobile applications, such as Telpark, for both off-street and on-street car parking. We plan
to continue to improve and extend the application of our cost-effective practices, such as
monthly contract-by- contract cost base reviews, the centralization of the daily management of
our off-street concessions business car parks from a remote location, our energy efficiency
programs and our on-street efficiency programs. Furthermore, we will continue to maintain our
well invested assets in order to keep our required level of maintenance capital expenditure
low, and we plan to eliminate certain overhead costs not required for continued operations.

**_Preserve and selectively expand our high quality portfolio of long-term concessions_**
We have a diversified portfolio of concessions and contracts in prime locations and will strive
to maintain and renew these concessions and contracts in order to maintain our stable cash
flow generation. We believe our infrastructure is well-invested. Our expansionary capital
expenditure is dependent on the opportunities available to us across our diversified portfolio.
Our total expansionary capital expenditure for the period from 2016 to 2018 was e83.1 million,
representing 13.5% of our total Adjusted Revenue for the same period (e35.1 million and
17.5% for the year ended December 31, 2016, e22.8 million and 11.0% for the year ended
December 31, 2017 and e25.2 million and 12.1% for the year ended December 31, 2018). As a
result, we intend to focus our efforts on renewing our portfolio of existing concessions and
contracts by maintaining our well invested assets in anticipation of future renewal capital
expenditure requirements and organically expanding our operations by capturing new
concessions and contracts. For example, due to our market leading position, scale and
expertise, we believe that we are well positioned to continue to grow our diversified portfolio
by renewing our existing contracts and concessions and capturing new contracts and
concessions from both existing customers seeking to award new concessions and from other
organizations looking to outsource the management of their parking facilities. For example, in
line with our historical strategy, we may acquire high quality smaller car parks in prime
locations and to incorporate them into our centralized control room, which will increase our
portfolio of assets that benefit from our mobile maintenance personnel. Due to our scale,
long-standing experience in this industry and established relationships with municipalities, we
are able to achieve significant synergies that also allow us to offer more competitive terms
than those offered by our competitors. We believe our position as one of the leading
concessionaires of off-street concessions and on-street concessions parking in Iberia, combined
with our long-standing relationships with a diverse number of local authorities and favorable
industry dynamics, including high barriers to entry, will assist us in continuing to implement
this strategy.

**_Strategic focus on off-street concessions business in Iberia_**
We will continue to focus on managing our core business segments within Iberia, principally
the off-street segment. We may opportunistically consider dispositions of non-core operations
and geographies, in order to enhance the risk profile of investment capital expenditures and
improve profitability. In addition, as part of our long-term strategy, we may consider strategic
options regarding the on-street concession business line, off-street contract management and
business outside of Iberia in order to fully focus on our off-street concession business, which
has a higher EBITDA Margin.

During the first nine months of 2019 we completed several acquisitions, such as the remaining
70% equity interest in Figueira Parques, an on-street concessionaire with eight years of
remaining life as of September 30, 2019, the Boulevard car park in San Sebasti´an with an

10


-----

average remaining life of 27 years as of September 30, 2019, and the Can Quit´eria car park in
San Cugat del Vall´es (where we already operate other assets, providing sufficient room for
yield management opportunities). On January 10, 2019, we completed the disposal of our
French business for a total consideration of e0.9 million. On September 5, 2018, we completed
the disposal of our UK business (other than our contract at Edinburgh Airport, which was
retained but which is expected to be terminated on January 31, 2020) to National Car Parks
Limited for a total consideration of e3.9 million. Both disposals demonstrate our continuing
commitment to reinforcing our portfolio of core assets in the Iberian off-street space.

We may also pursue ‘‘bolt-on’’ or strategic acquisition opportunities as and when value
accretive opportunities arise. We would expect to explore opportunities within our existing
core business and geographical footprint, being the off-street segment within the Iberia
region. We would also expect such opportunities to be capable of generating synergies with
our existing operations, growth opportunities where we can leverage our operating capabilities
and skill set, and/or achieve tax synergies, to create value.

Since September 30, 2019, we have completed three further bolt-on acquisitions, namely a
freehold car park in Almer´ıa, a 15-year agreement to operate one car park in Marbella and a
car park in the city center of Le ´on for a period of more than 50 years.

## History and Ownership

We commenced our operations in Iberia under the name Cintra Parking (the name of Empark
prior to its acquisition of Emparque) in Spain in the 1960s. Emparque commenced operations in
Portugal in the 1970s. Over the last five decades, our business has expanded through a
combination of organic growth and a series of mergers and acquisitions. The growth
culminated in July 2009, when the Group was created following a series of transactions
whereby Cintra Parking acquired and merged with Emparque. Since then, we have expanded
our operations with a sustained focus on Iberia.

On December 19, 2017, we were acquired by the Sponsor, a long-term investor providing
significant financial and operational backing to our business and projects, through the
Sponsor’s investment vehicle, Midco.

## Principal Shareholder

The Issuer is indirectly owned, through Midco, by the Sponsor, which is managed by MIRAEL, a
member of the Macquarie Group which, through its MIRA division, is the world’s largest
infrastructure manager by assets under management (according to IPE Real Estate). The
Macquarie Group is a global leader in the creation and management of specialist funds which
focus on infrastructure, real estate and adjacent sectors. As of September 30, 2019, MIRA had
more than e124 billion of assets under management with over 800 employees across 38 offices.
MIRA has been investing in Europe for over 20 year, with infrastructure portfolio companies
located in Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany,
Netherlands, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden and the UK.

## Recent Developments

**_Preliminary trading update_**
Based on preliminary management accounts for November 2019, we estimate that our Adjusted
EBITDA experienced growth for the 11-month period ended November 30, 2019, of
approximately 11% compared to the same period in 2018. This growth is in line with the trend
observed during the nine months ended September 30, 2019. During the same period our
off-street like-for-like revenues experienced growth in the range of 4.0% compared to the
same period in 2018. Since September 2015, we have experienced consistent, positive growth in
our off-street like-for-like revenues with the volume of transactions returning to the levels that
existed prior to the economic downturn in Iberia.

We use like-for-like revenues to provide a comparison between all revenues and other
operating income generated under our off-street and on-street concession business lines during
a specified month in the current year and all revenues and other operating income generated
under our off-street and on-street concession business lines during the same month for the
prior year, as adjusted to eliminate any new concessions and any concessions that expired or

were terminated during the periods being compared. Accordingly, if an off-street or on-street
concession was being managed in 2018, but was no longer managed in 2019, the revenues and
other operating income generated under that concession is not included for purposes of this
comparison.

**Optional redemption**

**Fixed Rate Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Prior to, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at the
option of the Issuer or the Parent Guarantor to redeem
all or a part of the Fixed Rate Notes at a redemption
price equal to 100% of the principal amount of such
Fixed Rate Notes plus the applicable ‘‘make-whole’’
premium described in this offering memorandum, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if
any, to the redemption date.

On or after, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at
the option of the Issuer or the Parent Guarantor, upon
not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ notice, to
redeem all or a portion of the Fixed Rate Notes at the
redemption prices set forth under ‘‘Description of Notes—
_Optional Redemption,’’ plus accrued and unpaid interest_
and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date.

Prior to, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at the
option of the Issuer or the Parent Guarantor on one or
more occasions to redeem the Notes in an aggregate
principal amount not to exceed 40% of the original
aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including any
additional Notes) using the net cash proceeds from
certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to
% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued
and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to
the redemption date, so long as at least 50% of the
aggregate principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes
(including any additional Fixed Rate Notes) remains
outstanding after each such redemption and each such
redemption occurs within 180 days after the date of the
relevant equity offering.

In addition, prior to, 2023, the Issuer may
redeem, during each twelve-month period commencing
with the Issue Date, up to 10% of the aggregate
principal amount of the Fixed Rate Notes outstanding
(including any additional Fixed Rate Notes), at its option,
at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal
amount of the Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid
interest and additional amounts, if any to the
redemption date.

**Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . . . . . . .** Prior to, 2021, the Issuer will be entitled at the
option of the Issuer or the Parent Guarantor to redeem
all or a part of the Floating Rate Notes at a redemption
price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes
plus the applicable ‘‘make-whole’’ premium described in
this offering memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid
interest and additional amounts, if any, to the
redemption date.

the option of the Issuer or the Parent Guarantor to
redeem all or a portion of the Floating Rate Notes at the
applicable redemption price set forth under the caption
‘‘Description of Notes—Optional Redemption—Floating
_Rate Notes’’ plus accrued and unpaid interest and_
additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date.

**Redemption for Taxation Reasons .** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation
or certain other circumstances, the Issuer may redeem the
Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a
redemption price of 100% of the principal amount
thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and
additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption.
See ‘‘Description of Notes—Redemption for Changes in
_Taxes.’’_

**Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Upon the occurrence of a Change of Control (as defined
herein), the Issuer may be required to offer to repurchase
all outstanding Fixed Rate Notes and/or Floating Rate
Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the
principal amount thereof on the date of purchase, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if
any, to the date of repurchase. However, a change of
control with respect to the Notes will not be deemed to
have occurred if a specified consolidated net leverage
ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See
‘‘Description of Notes—Repurchase at the Option of
_Holders—Change of Control.’’_

**Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the
ability of the Parent Guarantor and its restricted
subsidiaries to:

                   - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue
certain preferred stock;

                    - create or incur certain liens;

                   - make certain payments, including dividends or other
distributions, with respect to the shares of the Parent
Guarantor;

                  - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity;

                   - make certain investments;

                   - create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of
dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to
and on the transfer of assets to the Parent Guarantor
or its restricted subsidiaries;

                     - sell, lease or transfer certain assets including stock of
restricted subsidiaries;

                   - consolidate or merge with other entities;

                    - impair the security interests for the benefit of the
holders of the Notes; and

                  - amend certain documents.

exceptions and qualifications. See ‘‘Description of Notes—
_Certain Covenants.’’_

**Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . . . .** All payments made by or on behalf of the Issuer or any
of the Guarantors under or with respect to the Notes or
any Note Guarantee will be made free and clear of and
without withholding or deduction for, or on account of,
any present or future Taxes unless the withholding or
deduction of such Taxes is then required by law. If any
deduction or withholding for, or on account of, any such
Taxes will at any time be required to be made, the Issuer
or the relevant Guarantor will, subject to certain
exceptions, pay the additional amounts necessary so that
the net amount received by the holders of the relevant
Notes after the deduction or withholding will equal the
respective amounts that would have been received in
respect of such payments in the absence of such
withholding or deduction. See ‘‘Description of Notes—
_Additional Amounts.’’_

**Denominations . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be issued in registered form and
transferable in minimum denominations of e100,000 and
integral multiples of e1,000 in excess thereof.

**Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes have not been and will not be registered
under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any
other jurisdiction. The Notes are subject to restrictions on
transferability and resale. Holders of the Notes will not
have the benefit of any exchange or registration rights.
See ‘‘Notice to Investors.’’

**No Prior Market . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be new securities for which there is
currently no market. Although the Initial Purchasers have
informed the Issuer that they intend to make a market in
the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and may
discontinue market-making at any time without notice.
Accordingly, there can be no assurance that a liquid
market for the Notes will develop or be maintained.

**Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made for listing particulars to be
approved by the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and for the
Notes to be listed on the Official List of the Luxembourg
Stock Exchange and admitted to trading on the Euro MTF
market. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be,
or will remain, so listed and admitted to trading on the
Euro MTF market.

**Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** We will use the gross proceeds of the Notes as set forth
in ‘‘Use of Proceeds.’’

# Risk Factors

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the_
_following risks, together with other information provided to you in this offering memorandum,_
_in deciding whether to invest in the Notes. The occurrence of any of the events discussed_
_below could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial_
_condition. If these events occur, the trading prices of the Notes could decline, and we may not_

_immaterial could also adversely affect our business, results of operations, or financial condition_
_or our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and affect your investment._

## Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry

**_We are subject to intense competition that can constrain our ability to win, renew and acquire_**
**_parking concessions, as well as, in some instances reduced volumes of concessions being_**
**_tendered, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, results of_**
**_operations or financial condition._**
Our principal business activity is the development and management of off-street parking
concessions, primarily in Spain and Portugal. We also manage on-street parking concessions for
municipalities and, to a lesser extent, operate our off-street contract management business,
which involves contracts to manage parking lots on behalf of public authorities, primarily
airports and hospitals, and a limited number of private entities. The off-street and on-street
parking concession sector in Spain and Portugal is a highly competitive market, with a variety
of competitors ranging from small, local single-concession operators to large, regional, national
and international operators with a significant number of concessions. Some of these larger
competitors are divisions of diversified global corporations with substantial financial,
management and other resources and capabilities.

In Spain and Portugal, concessions for parking facilities are generally awarded and renewed
through competitive tenders. In the bidding phase of a concession, a significant number of
competing bidders may participate, including large construction groups and financial investors.
Generally, public tenders for off-street concessions and off-street contract management are the
most competitive, focusing primarily on economics. Public tenders for on-street concessions
tend to be less competitive, given the limited number of potential operators, and tend to focus
on the technical specifications of the concession and the demonstrated experience of the
bidder. There also may be significant competition to renew existing concessions. For example,
between January 1, 2016 and September 30, 2019, we had an average Replacement Rate of
approximately 189% for off-street concessions and 73% for total on-street concessions. The
Replacement Rate of off-street concessions was in part due to certain city councils, primarily
the City Council in Madrid, not retendering the concession at expiry as further discussed below.
This intense competition also materializes in a significant number of challenges by
non-awarded bidders in relation to the granting of car parks. We may lose bids where we do
not want to lower our return expectations or where a competitor may operate the concession
more efficiently (for example, if it manages other car parks nearby). If we are unable to
compete successfully in the future, our Replacement Rates may decline. In addition, there is
intense competition in Spain and Portugal to acquire any concessions that may be available for

41


-----

sale by their existing holders or owners (or to acquire concession operators). Certain
competitors and new entrants in the market may have greater financial resources, lower cost
bases than we have or more aggressive profitability thresholds. Consequently, they may be able
to bid more competitively than we can in public tenders for concessions or may be able to
offer more commercially favorable terms than us. As a result of such competition, we may not
be able to win new concessions or renew existing concessions on commercially favorable terms,
which are consistent with those we have negotiated in the past, or at all. Our inability to
successfully compete to win new concessions or to retain existing concessions could have a
material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

In addition, certain city councils, such as the City Council in Madrid, may choose not to
retender a car park once it has expired, but rather, in-source and operate the car parks
themselves, resulting in a loss of revenue, loss of opportunity to tender for a competitor’s
former concession and increased competition for other car parks. The loss of revenue, loss of
opportunity and increased competition resulting from insourcing of car parking concessions by
city councils could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or
financial condition.

**_We are dependent on the macroeconomic environment, and economic or financial instability in_**
**_Spain, Portugal and other countries in the EU and elsewhere may adversely affect our_**
**_operations and financial position._**
Our operations are principally located in Europe, mainly in Spain and Portugal, which for the
twelve months ended September 30, 2019 collectively accounted for 96.1% of our Adjusted
Revenue. Accordingly, our financial performance is particularly affected by economic and
financial conditions in Spain and Portugal, and our results of operations may be adversely
affected if difficult macroeconomic circumstances in Spain and Portugal cause a sustained or
significant decrease in the demand for parking services.

The EU as a whole is an important market for our business, and adverse economic effects
within the EU could have a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations or
financial condition. Conditions in Europe have resulted in increased volatility in global capital
markets, which could continue for the foreseeable future. The increased volatility may result in
a reduction in automobile travel of a discretionary nature, which could adversely impact traffic
levels in a number of locations where we operate parking facilities.

Continuing or renewed instability in the European markets, the stability of the euro or the EU
and the uncertainty derived from the refugee crisis has contributed to weak European
economic performance. Future developments may continue to be dependent upon a number of
political and economic factors.

Concerns persist regarding the debt burden of certain European countries and their ability to
meet future financial obligations, the overall stability of the euro and the suitability of the
euro as a single currency given the diverse economic and political circumstances in individual
member states of the Eurozone. These concerns could lead to the exit of one or more countries
from the Eurozone and the reintroduction of national currencies in such countries.

The UK’s decision by advisory referendum on June 23, 2016, to leave the EU (‘‘Brexit’’) and the
delivery by the UK of notice under Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty of its intention to leave the
EU has triggered a process of negotiations which will determine the terms of the UK’s
withdrawal from, and its future relationship with, the EU. It is possible that Brexit will cause
support in other EU countries to leave the EU to increase, which may further undermine the
stability of the EU. Brexit and its potential consequences could result in significant
macroeconomic deterioration, including, but not limited to, a decrease in GDP or trade in the
EU or other markets in which we operate and recession in the EU and/or the wider global
economy. The continuing unpredictability and potentially negative outcomes of Brexit could
have adverse consequences for the macroeconomic landscape in the EU as a whole or in certain

42


-----

EU member states and, as a result, our business, results of operating or financial condition may
be materially affected.

On October 1, 2017, the Catalan government announced and held a referendum which passed
in favor of Catalonia’s independence from Spain. However, the Spanish government did not
recognize it as legitimate and the Spanish courts declared it to be illegal. The Catalan
parliament subsequently approved Catalonia’s declaration of independence and in response the
Spanish government suspended Catalonia’s autonomy, dissolved the Catalan parliament, called
for new regional elections in December 2017 and arrested a number of public officials in
Catalonia (who were subsequently convicted by the Spanish Supreme Court in October 2019).
Following these events, tensions between the Spanish government and the Catalan
government remain high. The implications of the referendum and declaration of
independence, including the increasing political tensions and social unrest and disputes over its
legitimacy, could result in further political instability in Catalonia, which may negatively impact
our existing concessions in Catalonia and/or our ability to conduct future business in Catalonia.
Our business in Catalonia generated 6.7% of our Adjusted Revenue during the twelve months
ended September 30, 2019.

**_Our concessions are granted for a limited period of time and are subject to termination by the_**
**_granting authority on public interest grounds under circumstances stipulated under public law_**
**_or under the terms and conditions contractually agreed to as well as under the circumstances_**
**_set forth under applicable private law which may also apply with respect to surface rights_**
**_agreements._**
As of September 30, 2019, we had 285 off-street concessions (including 78 resident contracts)
and 114 on-street concessions (including seven contracts exclusively dedicated to tow-away
services) granted by municipalities and private entities. Our off-street parking concessions are
typically long-term arrangements with a maximum term of up to 50 years (although certain
older contracts and surface rights agreements in Portugal, such as Cam ˜oes or Alexandre
Herculano, have longer terms), and our on-street parking concessions in some cases could have
a maximum term of up to 25 years (or 20 years in Portugal). Moreover, while these concessions
are generally long-term arrangements, most of our concessions will be subject to a public
tender process at the end of their term. Out of our top 25 contracts by gross margin, four will
expire in the next two years. The loss of, or the renewal on less commercially favorable terms
of, a significant number of our existing concessions, or one or more of our largest concessions,
could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.

In addition, under applicable public laws, the relevant awarding authorities in Spain and
Portugal may terminate or recover concessions prior to their expiration on public interest
grounds, which is subject to interpretation, or under certain other circumstances stipulated
under applicable public law, subject to judicial review of the grounds for termination. See
‘‘Regulation—Spain—Early termination events and consequences’’ and ‘‘Regulation—Portugal—
_Termination of the concession.’’_

We are also subject to the termination rights set forth in the terms and conditions in our
agreements as well as private law which may also apply with respect to our surface rights
agreements.

Additionally, we have continued to operate a small number of our concessions past the
termination date before the contract is renewed and awarded to us or awarded to another
party. If we operate the concession beyond the term of the contract, we may have limited
recourse should the municipality terminate our services during such periods.

Generally, in the event of early termination of the concession not due to fault of the
concessionaire, the concessionaire will be entitled to compensation from the municipality for
the amount of the investments it has made in carrying out the terms of the concession based
on the degree to which the investments have been amortized. We may also seek compensation

provided by law or contract to cover our anticipated profits for the remaining duration of the
concession agreements if the awarding authority terminates the concession, although there can
be no assurance that we will be successful. Additionally, the public authority has some
discretion in interpreting the terms of the concession, especially when determining whether we
have complied with its terms. If we are unsuccessful in seeking compensation from the
municipality, our only recourse may be litigation, which may involve additional expenses and
an extended period of time to reach a resolution. Even if successful, the public authorities may

Additionally, certain of our contract management agreements allow the counterparty to

**_Changes in transportation and traffic patterns could materially adversely affect demand at our_**
**_facilities._**
A variety of factors are contributing to changes in the transportation industry that could have
a negative impact on our business, including changes in regulations, increased use of public
transport by end customers and car sharing, in particular in connection with our off-street
concessions where our EBITDA Margins are most affected by changes in demand, and to a
lesser extent in connection with our on-street concessions. Changes in environmental and
traffic control regulations could reduce demand for, and volumes in, our off-street parking
facilities that could adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.
For example some municipalities may impose traffic congestion charges in urban areas, reduce
the availability of on-street parking spaces, promote the use of public transportation in lieu of
automobiles or limit automobile access to urban areas as has been the case in Madrid Central
in Spain. The actions of regulators or international bodies, such as the recent referral of the
Spanish government to the Court of Justice of the EU for its alleged failure to protect its
citizens from air pollution, may also result in new or more stringent environmental and traffic
control regulations which could adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial
condition. Governments may also (whether or not as a response to regulatory or international
action or pressure) increase the tax levels on automobiles and petroleum for environmental
reasons, which may reduce traffic. We may also be materially adversely affected by temporary
or permanent changes to traffic routes or road closures, which may make it more difficult to
access our parking facilities and have a material adverse effect on our business, results of
operations or financial condition.

**_Changing consumer preferences may lead to a decline in parking demand, which could have a_**
**_material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations._**
Ride sharing services such as Uber or Cabify, along with the potential for electric and
autonomous vehicles or other new sharing services as with scooters, motorcycles or cars, may
lead to a decline in parking demand in cities and urban areas. While we devote considerable
effort and resources to analyze and respond to consumer preferences and changes to consumer
preferences and the markets in which we operate, consumer preferences cannot be predicted
with certainty and can change rapidly. Additionally, changes in consumer behaviors by using
mobile phone applications and on-line parking reservation services that help drivers reserve
parking with garage, lots and individual owner spaces cannot be predicted with certainty and
could change current customers’ parking preferences. If we are unable to anticipate and
respond to trends in the consumer marketplace and the industry, including but not limited to
market displacement by delivery service companies, car sharing companies and changing
technologies, it could constrain our business and have a material and adverse impact on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_In any particular period in which we experience a decrease in our revenues, our operating_**
**_expenses may not decrease at the same rate, which could have a material adverse effect on_**
**_our net cash flows, margins and profits._**
Many of the expenses associated with operating concessions are relatively fixed. These expenses
include personnel costs, interest, rent, property taxes, insurance and utilities. If we are unable
to decrease our costs significantly or rapidly when demand for our parking concessions
decreases, the decline in our revenues can have a particularly adverse effect on our net cash
flows and profits. This effect can be especially pronounced during periods of economic
contraction or slow economic growth. Where cost cutting efforts are insufficient to offset
declines in revenues, we could experience a material decline in margins and potentially
negative cash flows which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of
operations or financial condition.

**_In our off-street and on-street parking concessions, the tariff rates that we can charge our_**
**_customers are governed by our concession agreements._**
The revenues that we generate from our off-street and on-street parking concessions is
dependent on our tariff rates. The tariff structure is established under our concession
agreements and we generally have limited or no ability to independently raise tariffs beyond
the contractual provisions (usually, based on the rate of inflation, which in some cases requires
the approval of the relevant municipality). Before bidding for any concession project, we
conduct an analysis to determine the conditions under which we believe such concession can
be operated profitably. If the assumptions underlying our analysis prove to be incorrect and
our tariffs do not generate sufficient revenues to cover our costs, we may be unable to
increase our tariffs or reduce our costs in order for the concession to remain profitable, which
could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. This
effect could be compounded with respect to our long-term concession agreements.

**_According to the Law on the De-indexation of the Spanish Economy, new concession contracts_**
**_will not include the right to increase tariffs in accordance with inflation. Tariffs may only be_**
**_increased in line with the direct cost of the services and goods provided under each_**
**_concession contract._**
The Law on the De-indexation of the Spanish Economy, approved March 30, 2015, provides
new rules for the review of monetary values in contracts awarded by public authorities and
alters the past regime that was based on the principle of said monetary values being modified
by virtue of price indexes or formulas. Instead, it takes into account only significant costs of the
underlying goods and services of the activity (such as energy costs, or labor costs when the
labor force needed for the rendering of the service is deemed significant, but only up to the
increase of wages of civil servants), in proportion to the activity’s total costs. In any event,
financial costs and amortization costs, general expenditures and structural costs, as well as tax
increases, are excluded from update.

This new regulation has no retroactive effect and should not affect contracts already awarded
to Empark (nor any extension of the same) but it will affect contracts awarded after the entry
into force of the Royal Decree 55/2017, dated February 3, 2017. According to such Royal
Decree, the bidding terms and conditions of each contract will have to determine, whenever a
tariff update is foreseen, the update calculation method to be used in each case (which must
be elaborated by the awarding authority pursuant to the principles of the De-Indexation Law
and in view of the cost structures of at least five entities operating in the relevant sector).
Awarding authorities also have the possibility to provide for a standard calculation method
approved by the Council of Ministers for each sector (to date no such standard calculation
methods have been approved).
