# Regulation

The following is a brief summary of the regulatory regimes of Spain and Portugal applicable to
our business.

**_General_**
Car parks in Spain may be developed either privately or through the public concessionary
regime. Car parks developed through the public concessionary regime are usually located on
publicly owned land and involve the exercise of public administrative powers (principally by
municipalities). The legal regime governing car parks developed through the public
concessionary regime is more complex than that for private car parks. This is the reason why
this section is almost entirely devoted to car parks developed through the public concessionary
regime. The operation of public car parks, which is usually granted to private parties under
administrative concessions, is subject to the ongoing control of the public authorities that grant
the concessions.

Car parks that are privately developed are usually built on privately owned land and are
subject to a less complex regulatory regime than the regime applicable to car parks developed
through the public concessionary regime.

Law 40/2002 of November 14 (‘‘Law 40/2002’’) regulates car park agreements between the cark
park operators and end consumers and sets forth the duties of car park operators and their
liabilities for personal injury and property damage.

Under the relevant Spanish laws, the operator of a parking facility is liable for any damages to
the vehicle and its contents when certain conditions are met, including that movable
components, accessories or objects are expressly declared by the user, that the provider of
parking services expressly accepts their custody, and that the user complies with security
measures.

**_Off-street Car Parks_**
Off-street car parks can be classified as follows:

a) Ownership: The asset is owned by the company and is freely operated exclusively for its
own benefit. A parking contract with end users is ruled by Law 40/2002 on vehicle parking
which (since its amendment by means of Law 44/2006) sets forth that the price to be paid
by the user must be established by minutes of parking use without being able to charge
for parking time that has not been consumed. Law 40/2002 sets forth the duties of car
park operators and their liabilities for personal injury and property damage. In particular,
according to the law, the operator of a parking facility is liable for any damages to the
vehicle and its contents provided certain conditions are met.

b) Contract with a third party (public or private body):

i. Public contracts are typically awarded by municipalities who ‘‘own’’ the (car park)
public service. Public contracts may be classified as follows.

    - Public Works Concession: The concessionaire constructs and further exploits the car
park or it only operates the car park already constructed.

       - Those subject to the Law of Contracts with Public Authorities, a consolidated
text approved by Legislative Royal Decree 2/2000 of June 16 (‘‘TRLCAP’’) may
have a maximum term of: (i) 40 years if they are concessions for construction
and operation or (ii) 20 years if they are concessions only for the operation of
the car park.

122


-----

     - Those subject to Public Procurement Law 3/2011 (‘‘Law 3/2011’’) may have a
maximum term of 40 years.

    - Those subject to the current Public Procurement (Law 9/2017,)—must have a
limited duration, which is calculated in the procurement documents on the basis
of the relevant works and the investment to be recovered. If the term of the
contract exceeds five years, the maximum duration may not exceed the time
calculated as reasonable for the concessionaire to recover the investments made
for the exploitation of the works together with a return on the capital invested,
taking into account the investments necessary to achieve the specific contractual
objectives. In any case, the maximum duration of works concession contracts
cannot exceed 40 years.

   - Concession for the management of a public service (which may also include carrying
out some works).

    - Those subject to the Public Procurement Law 923/1965 may have a maximum
term of 99 years.

    - Those subject to the Public Procurement Law 13/1995 may have a maximum term
of 75 years.

    - Those subject to the TRLCAP or to Public Procurement Law 3/2011 may have a
maximum term of: (i) 50 years if they include construction and management or
(ii) 25 years if they are concessions only for the management of the car park.

Some of these contracts include a Public Domain Concession granted under the
Public Assets Law 33/2003, which may have a maximum term of 75 years. As a
consequence, the maximum duration for those contracts is 75 years.

   - Service concessions or simply service contracts: Pursuant to the current public
procurement Law 9/2017, public contracts related to car parking services could be
regulated under ‘‘service concessions’’ (which may also include carrying out works
related with the car parking infrastructure) or simply ‘‘service contracts.’’

As previously said, pursuant to the current public procurement Law 9/2017, the
service concession may entail the execution of works, in which case the maximum
duration of the contract will be 40 years. Otherwise, the duration of the services
concession may be up to a maximum of 25 years. Beyond this, provisions for
establishing duration are the same as for works concessions.

As a general rule, the service contracts subject to public procurement law 9/2017
may have a maximum term of five years. In exceptional cases, where the
amortization of the investment is a key factor for the provision of the services, the
terms of the contract may establish a higher maximum term.

ii. Private ‘‘Concessions’’ comprise contracts with a private entity to build and/or operate a
car park, the contract being subject to private common civil or commercial law and not
subject to specific term constraints (nor are they derived from the regulations on public
contracts).

iii. Management contracts comprise private contracts awarded by a public or by a private
entity. If the awarding entity is a public entity regulations on public contracts shall
apply to the awarding process, but the terms and conditions under which the contract
is executed are those set out in the contract itself and, accordingly, common civil or
commercial law will apply. Thus, management contracts are not subject to any
maximum term (nor are they derived from the regulations on public contracts). This

123


-----

conclusion may be slightly modified when the award entity is an entity within the
public sector.

**_On-street Car Parks_**
Municipalities are the ‘‘owners’’ of the on-street car park public service. Thus, its operation or
management always derives from a contract awarded by a municipality. On-street car parks fall
under the following categories:

a) Concession for the management of a public service. According to the Spanish Public Sector
Contracts (Real Decreto Legislativo 3/2011, de 11 de noviembre, por el que se aprueba el
_texto refundido de la Ley de Contratos del Sector P´ublico) (the ‘‘TRLCSP’’), these contracts_
may have a maximum term of 25 years. Note that these contracts are those which have
been awarded from the entry into force of the TRLCSP until the entry into force of
Law 9/2017.

b) Service contract: The operator provides a service and receives a payment in exchange.
According to the TRLCSP, these contracts may have a maximum term of four years with a
possible extension of two additional years.

c) Service Concession or simply Service contract (governed by Law 9/2017). Please, refer to
‘‘Off-street car park’’ section above.

**_Legal framework_**
The construction and operation of off-street parking facilities and the provision of on-street
parking services pursuant to contracts awarded by public authorities are regulated by public
procurement regulations currently, Law 9/2017. (Contracts awarded prior to the effectiveness of
Law 9/2017 are governed by the public procurement legislation in force when such contracts
were awarded: TRLCSP, Public Sector Contracts Law, 30/2007 of October 30, TRLCAP,
Law 13/1995 of May 18, on Contracts with the Public Authorities or Decree 923/1965, dated
April 8, approving the State Contract Law.

In addition, contracts entered into with municipalities are also usually governed by the
regulation ruling local entities services, approved by the Decree of June 17, 1955, as currently
in force. In addition, certain regions of Spain have enacted their own legislation. For example,
in the Catalonian autonomous region, Decree 179/1995 of June 13, approves the regulation of
local entities works, activities and services (‘‘ROAS’’).

Also, concessions are governed by the corresponding contractual documents which may include
additional requirements to those foreseen in said regulations, such as specific corporate
requirements for the concessionaire or change of control provisions.

**_Public tender process and award_**
Concessions for the construction and/or management of public car parks, as well as for the
provision of on-street parking services, are awarded through a public tender process. In this
public tender process, interested parties may submit their bids for the contract. The specific
conditions of the contract are set forth in the Terms of Tender and in the contract itself. These
conditions may differ and establish particular legal, economic and technical terms for each type
of contract and for each project without prejudice to the application of the relevant public
procurement legislation in force at the time the contract is awarded.

**_Term and renewal of public contracts_**
Within the maximum term established by the relevant applicable law, each particular contract
will have the duration of the contract set out in the Terms of Tender approved for the
contract.

124


-----

Additionally, the contractual term may only be extended under the circumstances set out in the
Terms of Tender and within the maximum extension terms mentioned therein and in the
applicable regulations. However, the concessionaire does not have a right to such an extension;
the Administration may grant it or not and provided it is so allowed by the applicable
regulations and the Terms of Tender.

The regulations on public contracts are becoming increasingly stringent as far as the extension
of public concessions is concerned and so are consequently the different administrations. These
restrictions are currently included in the public procurement law 9/2017.

Upon expiration of the contractual term (and its possible extensions, which necessarily need to
be granted or agreed in writing) the contract is terminated. The authority will then decide
whether it wants to award a new contract in a new open tender process or if it prefers to
provide the car-park service directly itself.

**_Powers of the awarding authority_**
The awarding authority is entitled to interpret the concession contract, resolve any doubt
regarding its execution, modify it for reasons of public interest, terminate it early and
determine the effects of such termination. Decisions adopted by the awarding authority are
immediately enforceable (even if the concessionaire is allowed to challenge such decision
before the tribunals and to request their precautionary suspension).

The right for the awarding authority to amend the contract must be duly justified in public
interest reasons that may affect the characteristics of the service provision or the tariffs to be
paid by users. If the modification affects the financial contractual regime, the administration
may have to compensate the concessionaire in order to maintain the financial balance of the
concession.

**_Restoring of the economic balance_**
Concessions are subject to risk (and venture) assumed by the concessionaire, which basically
means that the concessionaire runs the business at his own risk, including the need to carry out
at his own expenses certain investments such as technological updates, and is only entitled to
request a compensation if any of the following events occur (the administration may also
initiate a proceeding to re-balance the concession for its own benefit):

(a) ‘‘Ius variandi’’: mentioned above (please refer to section -Powers of the awarding
_authority)._

(b) ‘‘Factum principis’’: Any other action carried out by the public administration not directly
modifying the contract but which directly produces a ‘‘substantial imbalance’’ in the
contractual economics (for example, under certain circumstances, the opening by the same
administration of another car park which competes with the one awarded). Pursuant to
the current public procurement law 9/2017, factum principis may only be applied when the
contracting authority is the public administration which has carried out the action
producing the ‘‘substantial imbalance.’’ There is uncertainty as to whether the case-law
issued on the basis of the former public procurement regulations—which states that
factum principis could also be applied in those cases where the action producing the
‘‘substantial imbalance’’ is issued by public authorities other than the contracting
authority—remains applicable.

(c) Unpredictable risk: Any unforeseeable event, in which none of the contracting parties
intervenes, which produces a ‘‘substantial imbalance’’ in the contractual economics. In these
events, the ‘‘risk’’ is shared by both the administration and concessionaire, who will not be
entirely compensated. There is uncertainty as to whether the case-law issued on the basis
of the former public procurement regulations remains applicable.

(d) Force majeure.

125


-----

These causes for the restoring of the economic imbalance may be ruled by the Terms of Tender,
which may include certain particularities or modulations, without prejudice to the application
of the relevant public procurement legislation in force at the time the contract is awarded.

Compensation, which can eventually also take place in favor of the administration, may include
a modification of the tariffs to be paid by the users, the shortening or extension of the
contractual term or any other modification of the economic clauses contained in the contract.
As said above, the extension of the contractual term has been restricted in the most recent
regulations and can only be applicable under the circumstances set forth in Law 9/2017 when
the contract at stake is subject to the latter.

**_Concession tariffs and other remuneration arrangements_**
The Terms of Tender and the contract establish the tariff scheme to remunerate the
concessionaire. In exchange for operating the car parks, the concessionaires are generally
required to pay a fee to the granting authority.

Usually off-street car parks are remunerated in accordance with the use of the parking spaces.
Thus, short-term parking spaces (rotaci´on) are usually remunerated by a regulated tariff. The
right of the concessionaire to increase the tariffs to be paid by end users depends on what it is
set forth in the contract and in the Terms of Tender. Traditionally, amendments to tariffs had
been linked to the national, regional or sectorial Consumer Price Index.

However, the Spanish Economy De-indexation Law, approved on March 30, 2015, provides new
rules for the review of monetary values in the contracts in which the public sector intervenes,
establishing a regime based on the principle of said monetary values not being modified by
virtue of price indexes or formulas that contain the same. In any event, this new regulation has
no retroactive effect and should not affect contracts awarded before its enforcement.

In addition to the tariffs for the rotary use of the car park, as an ancillary activity, the
concessionaire is in some cases allowed to sell the right of permanent use for a certain number
of years of a limited number of parking spaces to local residents for a price established in the
contract, in accordance with the Terms of Tender. Note that in some concessions there is a ratio
between rotation and assignment of use that is compulsory for the concessionaire. It is also
permitted in many concessions to sell subscriptions to users for shorter terms (monthly, weekly
or daily passes, among others).

Other sources of income may be advertising within the car park, assignment of certain parking
spots to specific users such as hotels, or the implementation of ancillary activities such as car
washing.

However, these additional sources of income may be limited by the Terms of Tender or even
forbidden. Note that the concessionaire may also be required to assign some parking spots to
the granting authorities free of charge as part of the contractual arrangements.

On-street concessionaires are generally remunerated through a flat fee or by reference to a
percentage of the amount collected for the provision of the service less costs. Increase of tariffs
to be paid by end users need to be authorized by the granting authority.

The Terms of Tender and the contract establish the fee scheme that the concessionaire has to
pay to the granting authority. This fee may be due with certain regularity or may be payable
upfront. Failure to comply with fee requirements is generally a cause of termination of the
concession.

**_Assignment of the concessions and change of control_**
Traditionally, the assignment of the concession is in general, subject to the prior granting
authority’s consent, to be granted after having verified that all requirements are met. The most

126


-----

relevant requirement is that the assignee shall evidence before the granting authority that it
has the ability to operate the concession.

The transfer of the concessionaire’s shares (implying or not a direct change of control) is in
general not expressly foreseen in the contractual documentation or in the relevant
procurement regulations. However, in some cases, restrictions apply (e.g. obligation to notify or
to obtain prior approval).

Indirect transfer of the concessionaire’s shares (indirect change of control) is in general not
expressly foreseen in the contractual documentation or in the relevant procurement regulations
(e.g. port regulations do refer to this). However, in some cases the granting authority may
understand that an indirect change of control is subject to its prior approval when it implies a
change of control.

This interpretation is often based on the Spanish State Council doctrine set out in its
report 3375/2001, in which it considered that the transfer of a controlling stake in the
concessionaire may be considered to be a transfer of the concession, for which consent is
required.

Other corporate transactions may also be subject to specific requirements.

In addition, it should be noted that concessions entered into with the City Councils located in
Catalonia are governed by the ROAS. According to the ROAS, the transfer of the shares of the
concessionaire company without the authority’s prior approval is a termination event if it
implies a change of control. Note that, as per the second transitory provision of the ROAS, this
regulation applies to administrative procedures started after its enforcement. Indeed, there is
case law stating that the ROAS applies also to concessions granted before its enforcement.
Therefore, we cannot rule out that some City Councils in Catalonia consider that the ROAS
shall be applied also to concessions granted before its enforcement. In addition, it cannot be
ruled out that the authority considers that the ROAS subjects the indirect change of control of
the concessionaire to authorization.

Failure to comply with these requirements may lead to the termination of the concession for
which the concession will be held liable.

The current public procurement Law 9/2017 regulations on assignment essentially coincide with
the former ones. Law 9/2017 requires the possibility of assignment to be expressly established
as an option in the procurement documents. The contract cannot be assigned if the
procurement documents do not provide for it. However, the new regulation emphasizes the
regulated nature of authorizations of assignments and establishes tacit approval if the
contracting body does not rule on the assignment request within a term of two months.

**_Security over concession_**
The mortgage of a concession requires in general the prior approval by the granting authority.
This authorization will be without prejudice to the second authorization which will be required
upon enforcement of the mortgage (see Assignment section above). The contractual documents
may foresee the need to obtain the granting authority’s prior approval for the placement of
additional security relating to a concession.

In this regard, note that for example placing a pledge over the compensation or other credit
rights that the concessionaire is entitled to receive upon early termination in public works
concession awarded post-enforcement of Law 40/2015 is subject to the granting authority’s
prior approval. This provision has been upheld by Law 9/2017.

Failure to comply with these requirements may lead to the termination of the concession for
which the concession will be held liable and may imply the pledgee is not regarded as a
privileged creditor.

127


-----

**_Guarantees, insurance and other obligations with economic impact_**
Concessionaires are required to place economic guarantees before the granting authorities and
maintain them during the whole life of the concession. Note that in some cases the relevant
guarantee needs to be updated on a specific basis. These guarantees respond for the
obligations that the concessionaire has vis-`a-vis the granting authority. Although there is a
certain freedom for the concessionaire to choose how to place this guarantees, it is generally
made by means of a bank guarantee.

It is often the case that the Terms of Tender require that the concessionaire has certain
insurance policies in place during the whole duration of the concession, covering in general
third party liability and damages to the car parks. The Terms of Tender normally do not require
these insurance policies to be specific for a given car park, thus it allows that this requirement
is met through global insurance policies of the concessionaire.

Finally, it should be noted that the Terms of Tender may include the obligation for the
concessionaire to make specific investments either at the beginning or during the duration of
the concession.

Failure to comply with these requirements may lead to the termination of the concession for
which the concession will be held liable.

**_Early termination events and consequences_**
The different regulations on public contracts (1965, 1995, 2000, 2011 and 2017) provide for
certain events that may trigger the early termination of the concession contract, each of them
having particular consequences. In general, causes of termination are: (i) extinction of the legal
personality of the contracting company; (ii) declaration of insolvency in any other proceeding
of the concessionaire; (iii) mutual agreement between the administration and the
concessionaire; (iv) failure of the contractor to provide the final guarantee or the special
guarantee or complementary guarantee of the latter in time in the cases provided for under
law and the non-formalization of the contract in due time; (v) delay in the fulfillment of the
deadlines by the concessionaire; (vi) payment failure by the administration; (vii) failure to
comply with other essential contractual obligations; (viii) rescue of the concession or
suppression of the service by the Administration and (ix) those causes of termination that are
expressly established in the contract.

Traditionally, the concessionaire has the right to be compensated under law for the following:
(i) the non-amortized value of the land, premises and equipment used for the provision of the
service which revert to the administration, and (ii) the loss of value of any other investment
made in works and installations that do not revert to the administration.

If the early termination event is attributable to the concessionaire, damages and losses caused
to the administration will need to be indemnified by the concessionaire.

Additionally, in some cases in which the early termination event is attributable to the
administration, the concessionaire is also entitled to be compensated with the loss of profits
and other damages. In certain municipalities, there is the possibility of the administration
recovering the service awarded, the so-called ‘‘rescue’’ of the public service or public work by
the administration,’’ which means the unilateral declaration of the contracting body,
discretionally adopted, by which it terminates the concession, notwithstanding the good
management of the concessionaire.

128


-----

Law 40/2015 modified the effects of early termination of works and public services
management contract concessions. We may briefly recall the configuration of the effects of
termination as approved by Law 40/2015 and now upheld by Law 9/2017:

(a) When early termination occurs for reasons attributable to the contracting authority, the
concessionaire will receive the value of the investments minus their accounting
depreciation, as well as indemnification for loss and harm.

(b) When early termination occurs for reasons not attributable to the contracting authority
(including the insolvency of the concessionaire), the compensation to be received by the
concessionaire is identified with the ‘‘market valuation of the concession,’’ as determined in
a new award procedure via ascending-price auction, in which the sole award criterion is
the price.

**_Reversion and eventual exit payments_**
After conclusion of the concession contract the public service and/or the public works must
revert to the administration in an adequate state for its use and without any compensation.

According to the relevant municipal regulations on public contracts, the concession contract
shall determine the works and installations which will need to revert to the municipality by
expiration of the concessional term. The regulations on public contracts also provide that prior
to the reversion taking place, the administration will adopt the relevant measures so that the
reversion of the works and installations is carried out according to what is agreed in the
contract. This may entail the need for the concessionaire to carry out the relevant works or,
eventually, to provide the administration with an exit payment if the works and installations
are not in an adequate state for its use. In addition, some contractual arrangements may
foresee the need to make specific payments to the authority upon termination.

## Portugal

**_General_**
As in Spain, in Portugal car parks may be developed either privately or through the public
concessionary regime. Similar to Spain, car parks developed through the public concessionary
regime are located on publicly owned land and involve the exercise of administrative powers
relating to the regulation of traffic and local public highways. The legal regime governing car
parks developed through the public concessionary regime is more complex than that for
private car parks. Car parks developed through the public concessionary regime are managed
by a private party under an administrative concession or similar arrangement granted by a
public authority, and they are subject to the ongoing control of the public authorities that
grant the concession or arrangement.

Car parks that are privately developed are usually built on privately owned land and are
subject to a less complex regulatory regime than the regime applicable to car parks developed
through the public concessionary regime. The terms and conditions applicable to privately
operated car parking facilities are contractual in nature although subject to the applicable
mandatory private law provisions.

Enforceability of rights under the above mentioned agreements towards third parties may
depend on their prior registration before the competent land registry offices, notably in the
case of ownership rights, surface rights and lease agreements with a term equal to in excess of
six years. Private car park operators are generally required to obtain municipal licenses in order
to build and operate the car park and are subject to certain legislation governing the car park
industry, particularly with regard to health and safety, tariffs and consumer rights. For example,
Decree-Law 81/2006, of April 20, which regulates the use and access conditions to car parks, is
applicable to privately developed car parks.

129


-----

There is no specific legislation relating to the liability of car park operators for injury and
property damage in car parks and therefore the general liability rules of the Portuguese Civil
Code are applicable. According to these general rules, car park operators may be liable for
injury and property damage to the extent that the damage in question results from an
intentional or negligent violation of a third party right. In off-street car parks, car park
operators may also be liable for damages caused by third parties (for example theft) in cases
where the car park operator assumes an obligation to assure the safety of the vehicles parked.
However, in most cases, car park operators explicitly exclude these obligations in the terms and
conditions of use posted in the facility for damages caused by third parties to the vehicles
parked. As far as we could ascertain, there are no court decisions recognizing the validity of
this exclusion in situations where the car operator had included such exclusion in the
conditions of use posted in the facility.

The following summary covers car parks operated through the public concessionary regime and
accordingly subject to the public regulatory regime.

**_Applicable legislation_**
The construction and operation of public parking structures and on-street parking are
regulated by public laws governing the formation and performance of public contracts, by
municipal regulations and by the contractual arrangements entered between the operator and
the municipalities. The construction and operation of public parking structures and on-street
parking are regulated by public laws governing the formation and performance of public
contracts by municipal regulations and by the contractual arrangements entered between the
operator and the municipalities.

An administrative concession is used by public authorities to promote the development of
public works by private entities that will subsequently operate such public works (a ‘‘public
_works concession’’) or to contract a private entity to operate a certain public service, in_
principle, without involving any kind of construction (a ‘‘public service concession’’), although
some public service concessions may imply also some construction works as an ancillary
obligation.

A surface right is a right to build and maintain a certain construction for a specified period of
time over the property of the granting authority. Surface rights agreements entered into with
public entities for the construction of off-street parking facilities, whilst subject to the rules
applicable to the formation and performance of public contracts as referred to above, may also
be subject to private law.

The concessions for the construction and management of parking facilities and on-street
parking are currently regulated in Portugal through the Public Contracts Code, approved by
Decree-Law 18/2008, of January 29 (‘‘Public Contracts Code’’), which includes the general
provisions relating to the formation, performance and termination of concession agreements.
Prior to the Public Contracts Code, these agreements were regulated by Decree-Law 59/99, of
March 2 (which governed public works contracts), and 390/82, of September 17, (which
imposed certain rights and obligations with respect to any concessions granted by
municipalities). These prior laws still govern the concession agreements which formation
procedures were initiated before the Public Contracts Code entered into force. One of the most
relevant differences between the Public Contracts Code and the former legislation with regard
to administrative concessions is that, upon the enactment of the Public Contracts Code, the
duration of an administrative concession is no longer subject to a strict duration rule. Instead,
under the Public Contract Code, the duration of concession contracts is determined taking into
account the period required to reimburse and remunerate, under normal market conditions,
the concessionaire’s capital investment. In addition, the concessions in the public domain are
also subject to Decree-Law 280/2007, of August 7, that sets forth the legal regime applicable to
the management of public property. In some situations the public-private partnership
regulation set forth in Decree-Law 86/2003, of April 26, as amended by Decree-law 14/2006, of

130


-----

July 27, or in Decree-Law 111/2012, of April 26 (which revoked Decree-Law 86/2003, of
April 26), may apply.

Historically, the concessions’ duration limitation has caused public authorities to adopt surface
rights agreements (instead of concession agreements) in respect of off-street parking in order
to allow longer duration periods given that construction of parking facilities involves
investments that could not be reimbursed within such a short period of time. Surface rights are
not subject to a specific term limitation. According to the applicable rules, the construction and
operation of off-street parking facilities with respect to publicly owned land subject to the
public domain legal regime (the ‘‘public domain’’) should take place under concession
agreements and, conversely, the construction and operation of off-street facilities with respect
to publicly owned land not subject to the public domain legal regime (the ‘‘private domain’’)
could be made through these agreements. In order to overcome the above referenced term
limitation applicable to concessions and due to this distinction, the general practice adopted by
municipalities has been to disaffect parcels of land from the municipal public domain and
re-incorporate those parcels in the municipal private domain precisely to allow the execution of
surface rights agreements in order to take advantage of the longer term permitted under
surface rights agreements.

Currently, the award of surface rights agreements (in respect of publicly-owned properties) for
the construction of off-street parking facilities may also be subject to tender procedures
established in the Public Contracts Code (to the extent that they contain typical stipulations
and characteristics of the agreements subject to this Code) and, in addition, is subject to
Decree-Law 280/2007, of August 7, that sets forth the legal regime applicable to the
management of public property. If the tender surface right contracts qualify as administrative
contracts, then the administration contracts’ performance regime of the Public Contracts Code
will also apply. Prior to the enactment of this legislation, the execution of such surface rights
agreements was also subject to Decree-Laws 59/99, of March 2, 390/82, of September 17, and
794/76, of November 5. These prior laws still govern older surface rights agreements which
formation procedures were initiated before the Public Contracts Code was enacted.

**_Public tender process and award_**
The public authorities enter into contracts with the private parties selected through tender
processes in which the interested parties may submit their tenders. The specific conditions of
these contracts are set forth in the Terms of Tender (‘‘Caderno de Encargos’’) and in the
contract (which is based on the Terms of Tender). These conditions may differ among contracts
and establish particular features for each specific project, while using the aforementioned legal
framework as a reference. Theoretically, the granting of a surface right could be made,
according to Decree-Law 280/2007, of August 7, by direct award or through a negotiated
procedure, however, given the fact that the surface rights in question substantially contain the
typical elements of a concession, they are usually awarded through the aforementioned tender
procedures.

**_Types of contracts_**
Typically, car parks operate under one of the following three different classes of contract: (i) a
contract for concession of management of a public service without works; (ii) a contract for
concession of public works; and (iii) a surface rights agreement.

Most contracts for the operation of on-street car parks take the form of a concession for the
management of a public service without works, provided that it is not necessary to build any
relevant infrastructure for their operation.

Most of the contracts currently in force for the off-street car parks are operated under surface
rights agreements awarded by the municipalities, since, as mentioned above, prior to the Public
Contracts Code’s entry into force in 2008, concessions awarded by municipalities were limited
to a term of 20 years. Although even after the enactment of the Public Contracts Code the

131


-----

municipalities maintain the previous trend of resorting to surface rights agreements for the
off-street car parks, it is possible that in the future car parks developed through the public
concessionary regime will be more often awarded through concession contracts.

**_Term and renewal of administrative concessions and surface rights_**
Currently, the applicable legislation does not impose a specific term limit for administrative
concessions, and their duration shall be determined in the contract taking into account the
reasonable period required under normal market conditions to reimburse and remunerate the
concessionaire’s capital investment. In the absence of such contractual clause stipulating the
duration of the concession agreement, the Public Contracts Code sets forth a 30-year term.

Upon expiration of the agreement, the contract cannot be renewed without a prior public
tender procedure taking place. Nevertheless, under certain circumstances, the agreement may
be extended provided that such possibility had been contemplated by the contract. However
rights and certain preference rights for the grant of new surface rights may be deemed null
and void.

Surface rights agreements entered into in connection with publicly owned properties do not
have a statutory term limit but will have the term specified in the contract. This term is
determined in accordance with public interest criteria and taking into account the economic
balance of the service that will be operated under the agreement. The applicable legislation
does not allow the renewal of surface rights upon expiration of the contract. Surface rights
agreements normally have a long-term and, upon their expiration, a new agreement will need
to be executed following a public tender if the Public Contracts Code applies. Otherwise, a
limited, a negotiated or a direct award procedure could apply.

**_Economic-financial balance_**
In general, public contracts are executed based on the principle that the business risk is
assumed by the private entity.

Notwithstanding this, the law foresees certain situations that may lead to a modification of the
terms initially agreed in order to ensure that the public interest pursued by the contract is not
affected in the face of abnormal and unpredictable circumstances or unilateral modification of
the contract imposed on public interest grounds by the public entities. In light of the Public
Contracts Code, the concessionaire or the holder of a surface right (to the extent that such
right contains typical stipulations and characteristics of the agreements subject to the Code) is
only entitled to the re-establishment of the economic balance of the contract in the following
situations (without prejudice to specific re-establishment triggers that may be foreseen in the
relevant agreement):

(i) when the circumstances upon which the parties have grounded their decision to enter into
contract suffer an abnormal and unpredictable modification imputable to the awarding
authority acting beyond the contractual frame; or

(ii) when the agreement is modified by the public entity for public interest reasons.

According to the Public Contracts Code, the means to re-establish the financial balance may be
set out in the contracts. There are no legislative limits with respect to the mechanisms that may
be adopted, but often such mechanisms include revision of tariffs, adding parking spaces or a
provision stating that the authority and the concessionaire shall jointly seek an agreement to
re-establish the financial balance of the contract. In the absence of contractual provisions
setting out the means to re-establish the financial balance, the Public Contracts Code
(applicable to concessions and possibly to the surface rights agreements if the tender program
determines its applicability or because the contract is materially a concession contract)
stipulates that re-establishment of the balance may notably be achieved through the extension
of the contractual term, through the revision of prices or through the payment of

132


-----

compensation. Any other situation involving an abnormal and unpredictable modification of
the circumstances will trigger the right to a modification of the agreement or to receive
compensation to the private entity (without necessarily implying the re-establishment of the
initial economic balance).

The legal framework applicable to concessions and surface rights agreements prior to the entry
into force of the Public Contracts Code did not specify the rebalancing right and mechanism, at
least in such detail. However, either by appealing to general rules and principles of Law or
through the use of contractual conditions establishing the rebalance right, one could sustain
such rebalancing right in as those currently foreseen in the Public Contracts Code. Therefore
from a practical point of view, the final applicable framework may not differ substantially from
the one currently in force.

There is no specific claim procedure prescribed by law to apply for the financial rebalancing of
the contract. Under circumstances that would trigger the rebalancing mechanism, the
concessionaire or holder of the surface right shall apply to the public entity within the
contractual framework and in accordance with the general rules applicable to contracts. In
practical terms, a written notice should be sent to the public entity stating the facts underlying
the rebalancing request and the relevant legal provisions and proposing the mechanism to
restore the economic balance of the contract. Normally, this will entail a negotiation with the
awarding entity. Should the latter accept the proposed mechanism, this would typically be
formalized by means of an amendment to the agreement. In the absence of a favorable
decision or in the absence of a decision within a reasonable period of time, a judicial claim
may be filed with the administrative courts or with an arbitral (depending on the dispute
resolution mechanism foreseen in the agreement), in order to obtain a ruling on the financial
rebalancing. The duration of a judicial court procedure is difficult to determine, as it depends
on numerous factors, such as the number of appeals to be completed in order to obtain a
definitive judicial resolution (generally two appeals), or the volume of affairs affecting, in each
moment, the competent court. Currently in Portugal judicial procedures in administrative courts
may last more than three years but there is no assurance the process will be completed within
this time frame.

**_Concession tariffs and other remuneration arrangements_**
The relevant Terms of Tender and the relevant contract establish the tariff scheme to
remunerate the concessionaire/holder of the surface right.

Normally with off-street structures the concessionaire/holder of the surface rights is
remunerated based on the collection of the tariffs established in the contract, which are
reviewed periodically based on the consumer price index. In addition, a fixed price or an
annual amount may also be payable by the concessionaire/holder of the surface right to the
municipality in consideration for the concession or surface right awarded.

With respect to on-street parking, normally the concessionaire agrees to deliver to the
municipality a percentage of the tariffs collected or, in some cases, a fixed amount and, in
other cases, a combination of a fixed amount plus a percentage of the tariffs. It is customary
for the concessionaire/holder of surface right to include the tariffs in its offer to tender and
subsequently propose to the awarding authority for its approval revisions of the tariffs as
allowed by the contract.

**_Authorizations and change of control clauses_**
In some of the contractual arrangements, municipalities impose certain restrictions on the
shareholder of the concessionaire and the guarantees that such concessionaire can grant to
third parties, such as the need for prior authorization to create a mortgage over the concession
or, sometimes, change of control clauses.

133


-----

Legislation relating to these matters does not expressly require prior authorization for share
transfers of the concessionaire or changes of control in it. Nevertheless, certain specific Terms
of Tender and contracts, or their interpretation by the public authority, may require prior
consent for such transactions. However, the applicable legislation expressly requires prior
authorization for mortgages or charges over assets included in the concession or over the
surface right. The need for authorization could also result from the fact that the public tender
established prerequisites for the qualification or the evaluation of the proposals that were met
by the tenderer with recourse of the parent company’s qualifications or expertise.

**_Termination of the concession_**
Under the current regulatory regime, apart from a termination resulting from contractual
breaches, concession and surface rights agreements may be terminated by the public entity as a
result of the following: (i) at any time due on public interest grounds, provided that
appropriate compensation is paid to the concessionaire/holder of the surface rights (to be
calculated according to the contractual regime or, in the absence of contractual provisions, in
accordance with the law); (ii) unauthorized assignment or transfer of the concession or surface
right; (iii) unauthorized creation of mortgages or other charges over the concession or surface
right; and (iv) certain other events specified in the Public Contracts Code. In addition, the
public entity may be entitled to assume the management of the concession or surface right
temporarily in case of severe breach of contract, such as the failure to perform or pay amounts
due. During such period, the contract will be suspended and if the operation is not resumed,
the agreement may be terminated.

Contracts usually include provisions stipulating the formula that shall be used to calculate the
indemnity payable in event of early termination grounded on public interest. In general, the
formulae are designed to reflect an amount of indemnity calculated on the basis of the
investment that was not amortized and such formulae do not usually cover loss of profit, which
needs to be claimed on the basis of general principles under law. If the municipality and the
concessionaire cannot agree on compensation, the concessionaire may file a claim against the
municipality.

**_Liability and compensation for termination of concession contract_**
In the event of termination of the contract due to breach by the public authority, the latter
will be liable for payment of the loss and damage caused to the concessionaire/holder of the
surface right. Similarly, the termination of the contract due to intentional breach by the
concessionaire/holder of the surface right will result in such entity being liable to indemnify the
authority for the loss and damage caused. Such indemnification may be sought through the
enforcement of the security granted by the breaching party, if applicable.

134


-----

# Business

## Overview

We are one of the leading concessionaires and operators of parking infrastructure in the
Iberian Peninsula, as measured by number of parking spaces and revenues. We mainly operate
underground car parks (‘‘off-street’’), as well as some parking areas on city streets (‘‘on-street’’)
under concessions and surface rights agreements from public authorities. As of September 30,
2019, our portfolio comprised 403 concession contracts in 145 municipalities under which we
manage over 436,920 parking spaces, including 33,366 resident spaces, primarily in Spain and
Portugal, and marginally in Andorra, Turkey and the UK. For the twelve months ended
September 30, 2019, our revenues were e197.3 million, our Adjusted Revenue was
e196.4 million, our Adjusted EBITDA was e90.6 million and we had an Adjusted EBITDA Margin
of 46.1%. Our operations in Spain and Portugal, respectively, represented 70.7% and 25.4% of
our Adjusted Revenue, 68.2% and 28.9% of our gross profits and 82.9% and 13.9% of our
parking spaces for the twelve months ended September 30, 2019. Our off-street concession
business and on-street concession business generated 56.5% and 35.5% of our Adjusted
Revenue, respectively, and 83.9% and 16.5% of our Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, for the
twelve months ended September 30, 2019.

We have served the Iberian market since the late 1960s. We believe this has given us a ‘‘first
mover’’ advantage, whereby we have continually secured long-term concessions and built a
portfolio of prime parking locations in Spain and Portugal, including in city centers, airports
and other high density traffic areas, such as hospitals and business districts. Due to a variety of
physical, regulatory and other constraints such as cost of space, we believe that there is limited
opportunity to develop alternative parking options in many of these prime areas, allowing us
to benefit from captive demand with limited competition. Due to an overall lack of available
land in major cities within our geographical focus, and an overall urbanization trend in the
current macroeconomic climate, we do not expect this competitive advantage to diminish in
the foreseeable future.

We generate revenues under three business lines:

- Off-street concessions. Our off-street concession business primarily comprises long-term
concessions, with contract lengths generally ranging from 20 to 50 years, granted by
municipalities to develop and operate parking facilities, primarily underground and multistory, and generated 56.5% of our Adjusted Revenue (e111.0 million) and 83.9% of our
Adjusted EBITDA (e76.0 million), and had an Adjusted EBITDA Margin of 68.5%, for the
twelve months ended September 30, 2019. Under these contracts, we are generally required
to invest in the construction of a new parking facility (a ‘‘green field’’ concession) or make an
upfront payment to the municipality for an existing parking facility (a ‘‘brown field’’
concession). We operate each parking facility on a long-term basis and generate our fees
based on tariffs charged to car park users, as set out in the relevant concession or surface
rights agreement, which typically increase each year in line with inflation. We generally
retain all fees generated from operating the relevant parking facility and are responsible for
all expenses relating to operating and maintaining the parking facility during the term of
the concession. With respect to ‘‘brown field’’ concessions, we may pay an annual concession
fee to the municipality, an upfront fee or a combination of both. In addition, we sell a
limited number of parking spaces to local residents, receiving a monthly fee for the
rendering of maintenance services, as an ancillary activity in connection with the
development of some parking facilities. As of September 30, 2019, we had 285 off-street
concession contracts (including 78 resident contracts) under which we manage approximately
120,003 parking spaces. The Weighted Average Remaining Duration of our off-street
concessions was approximately 25 years as of September 30, 2019.

135


-----

- On-street concessions. Our on-street concession business comprises concessions, with contract
lengths generally ranging from five to 20 years, granted by municipalities to manage metercontrolled on-street parking, and generated 35.5% of our Adjusted Revenue (e69.7 million)
and 16.5% of our Adjusted EBITDA (e15.0 million), and had an Adjusted EBITDA Margin of
21.5%, during the twelve months ended September 30, 2019. For these types of contracts,
we typically receive fixed fees that are inflation-indexed and which cover the yearly
amortized amount of our initial investment and operating costs and reasonable rate of
return. In a number of concessions, the contract also includes a variable incentive element
(which may be based on a percentage of the collected meter receipts, the number of parking
spaces or certain other indicators) to align the concessionaire’s objectives with optimizing
revenue collection. As of September 30, 2019, we had 114 on-street concession contracts
(including seven contracts exclusively dedicated to tow-away services) under which we
manage approximately 230,966 parking spaces. We have a long-standing presence in many
cities and a successful relationship with many municipalities which we believe provides us
with a competitive advantage in securing new off-street business. The Weighted Average
Remaining Duration of our on-street concessions was approximately five years as of
September 30, 2019.

- Off-street contract management. Our off-street contract management business involves
contracts to manage parking facilities on behalf of public authorities, primarily airports, as
well as a limited number of private entities. Our off-street contract management business
generated 8.0% of our Adjusted Revenue (e15.7 million) and did not affect our Adjusted
EBITDA in a meaningful way in the twelve months ended September 30, 2019. As of
September 30, 2019, we had four off-street management contracts. Under these contracts,
we operate and manage parking facilities with approximately 85,951 parking spaces on
behalf of third parties in exchange for a fixed fee. Although it is a relatively small part of
our overall business, our off-street contract management business line allows us to gain
expertise in managing complex operations, as well as to improve our access to municipalities
and build local market knowledge.

## Strengths

We believe that we have several competitive advantages in the car park sector in Iberia,
including our long-term contract revenues, diversified business profile, assets with low demand
risk and market leadership. As a result of these strengths, together with the stable regulatory
environment and favorable industry dynamics, our business benefits from a high level of
stability and recurring cash flows.

**_Uniquely positioned for growth on the back of Iberia’s favorable macroeconomic trends_**
The macroeconomic environment in Spain and Portugal, our largest geographic markets in
terms of revenues, has continued to improve. The car park industry has recently been growing
in Iberia, mainly driven by this factor as well as urbanization and an increase in the number of
cars. The profitability of the sector is generally improving, supported by scale efficiencies, the
implementation of cost savings programs and the utilization of innovative industry technology
(including digitalization), among other factors. See ‘‘Industry.’’ We believe that we are well
positioned to benefit from the continued improvement in the economic environment in Iberia
resulting in organic growth opportunities for us. The economic growth in Iberia may also lead
to consolidation opportunities that provide room for further non-organic growth. We believe
that improvements in our business activity and revenues, along with a sustained cost-base, in
connection with such economic improvement, together with our various cost efficiency
initiatives, will have a positive effect on our EBITDA.

During the period from 2016 to 2018, we benefitted from the good macroeconomic landscape
in Iberia and were able to increase our Like-for-like revenues on a CAGR basis at a higher rate
than the CAGR of GDP in Iberia over the same period.

**_Leading car park concessionaire in Iberia benefitting from scale and high barriers to market_**
**_entry_**
We are one of the leading car park concessionaires in the Iberian parking infrastructure
concessions market both by revenue and total number of parking spaces and were the leading
car park operator in Portugal in terms of revenue, and the leading car park operator in Spain
by number of spaces, for the year ended December 31, 2018. As of September 30, 2019, we
managed 362,294 parking spaces in Spain (including 33,366 resident spaces), 60,678 in Portugal,
4,075 in Turkey, 8,500 in the UK and 1,373 in Andorra. We had approximately 25.0 million car
parking transactions in the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, based on the number of
payments made across all our car parks. Our size and growth have allowed us to achieve
significant economies of scale, and the scope of our operations, combined with the various cost
management measures we have implemented, have allowed us to maintain our Adjusted
EBITDA levels. For example, our centralized control room system controls and manages a
substantial majority of our off-street concessions business’ parking facilities from a remote
location, which has allowed us to improve our cash flow and reduce operating expenses,
headcount and personnel costs (we reduced the number of operators per car park by more
than half) without impacting our service quality and customer satisfaction levels. This is a key
driver for efficiency gains and margin improvements, particularly in the off-street segment,
allowing for more competitive pricing when bidding for new contracts and placing us in a
strong position for additional growth. In addition, our mobile maintenance personnel are
responsible for the maintenance of several car parks within a defined geographic area, which
reduces personnel expenses and standby time. This has allowed us to reallocate personnel to
perform certain functions previously outsourced, thereby reducing our reliance on third-party
service providers. Our economies of scale enable us to be a consolidation platform for smaller
Iberian parking operations, and allow us to undertake valuable new concessions and
acquisitions of smaller players. For example, when we acquired Boulevard in August 2019 we
integrated the company into our centralized control room system to reduce the number of
staff on site, ensured maintenance works were performed by dedicated local teams and
arranged for management services relating to human resources, tax or accounting, to be
conducted by centralized management teams. In addition, through our experienced
management team and our long-standing reputation in the industry, we have been able to
develop and maintain important relationships with the various municipalities with which we do
business, thereby reducing our dependence on any single local authority or region.

We believe the upfront cost and difficulty in obtaining planning permission to build new high
density car parks in city centers, together with the favorable regulatory regime that applies to
concession agreements in Spain and Portugal as discussed under ‘‘—Stable regulatory
_environment with downside protection’’ below, as well as the scale required to operate car_
parks efficiently present significant barriers to entry in the car park industry. The stringent
regulatory framework governing parking concessions in Iberia reduces the risk of new
competitors entering the market. For example, due to the terms and lengths of concession
contracts (the average weighted life for off-street concessions is approximately 25 years as of
September 30, 2019), competitors can be locked-out of the off-street concessions business for
long periods of time. In addition, our size provides us with the scale required to operate a car
park portfolio efficiently. For example, our scale enables us to share resources among our car
parks including maintenance and supervisory staff, as well as management resources in respect
of accounting, marketing, human resources, insurance and tax matters. The number of our
locations also gives us a commercial advantage as we are able to anticipate customer needs
across multiple locations. In addition, the high initial investment required to produce efficient
IT resources is beyond the reach of smaller competitors. Between January 1, 2016 and
December 31, 2018, we invested an average of e1.5 million per annum in IT resources. Unlike
smaller operators, we can price into our bids the efficiencies that we can generate through our
portfolio, and thus offer more attractive terms to municipalities. Also, as there is a lack of
available land in the major city centers of Iberia, there are limited opportunities to construct

138


-----

new car parks, and our scale provides us with numerous consolidation and expansion
opportunities, which many smaller competitors are unable to take advantage of.

**_High degree of diversification_**
Our business benefits from a portfolio which is highly diversified in terms of the following:
number of contracts, number of municipality clients and types of parking services we deliver.
We are also diversified through our three business lines, each of which has different risk
profiles and capital requirements, but with similar operational and managerial requirements.
As of September 30, 2019, we had 403 contracts, comprising 285 off-street concession contracts
(including 78 resident contracts), 114 on-street concession contracts (including seven contracts
exclusively dedicated to tow-away services) and 4 off-street management contracts. Our
off-street concession business line is further diversified in terms of location, municipality, end
user and type of contract (business district, hospitals, shopping areas and tourism). We believe
our limited reliance on any single contract is a significant factor in diversifying our source of
revenues and therefore reduces our cash flow volatility. While our ten largest off-street car
parks represented 20.2% of our total gross profit for the twelve months ended September 30,
2019, our largest car park represented less than 2.7% of our total gross profit during the same
period. We believe our diversified business portfolio differentiates us from other infrastructure
companies, who typically rely on a smaller number of larger contracts or concessions, with a
greater concentration of risk. We are highly selective as to our management contracts and we
only provide such services to the extent that they comply with certain margin and profitability
criteria.

**_Strategically located assets with attractive concessions and limited demand risk_**
We believe that our infrastructure portfolio is well invested. Our on-street concession and
off-street contract management businesses have low demand risk because we are generally
paid a fixed fee for the services we provide, regardless of occupancy of the car park. Although
our off-street concession business is subject to demand risk and fluctuations in volumes, we
believe the prime locations of our concessions will continue attracting car park users and
ensuring stable utilization levels given our car parks are located in high traffic areas at or
within close proximity to city centers. Our business was created as a result of the acquisition of
the two historical leaders in the parking concessions market in Spain and Portugal, each with
prime concessions already in place. As a result, we were able to construct car parks in strategic
locations, including Playa de la Concha in San Sebasti´an and Cam ˜oes in Lisbon, and take
advantage of the existing concessions which were located within close proximity to city centers
and in high traffic areas. Therefore, we believe that we enjoy a prime position in the relevant
local area with respect to a significant proportion of our parking facilities. Moreover, the high
density of city centers together with planning regulations make the approval process for
‘‘green field’’ concessions difficult, effectively limiting the supply of parking spaces in a given
area. Additionally, many of our concessions in strategic locations have a long remaining life,
such as Cam ˜oes, Lisbon (32 years, 340 car park spaces), Playa de la Concha, San Sebasti ´an
(39 years, 655 rotation spaces plus 619 resident spaces), Joan de Borb ´o, Barcelona (20 years,
617 rotation spaces plus 14 resident spaces), Restauradores, Lisbon (28 years, 545 car park
spaces) and Boulevard, San Sebasti´an (27 years, 381 rotation car park spaces and 630 resident
spaces), in each case as of September 30, 2019. The prime positions of our car parks and the
difficulty in building new car parks helps to reduce the demand risk in our off-street concession
business.

**_Stable regulatory environment with downside protection_**
The regulatory framework governing off-street and on-street parking concessions in Spain and
Portugal affords certain protections to the concessionaire. We and other car park
concessionaires that operate in Iberia have historically benefitted from a ‘‘rebalancing’’ clause
under the relevant concession legislation in Spain and Portugal, which may also apply to
Portuguese public surface rights agreements. Under certain circumstances, a change in the

139


-----

balance of the economic terms and conditions of the concession that is adverse to the
concessionaire will trigger a right of the concessionaire to seek compensation or a
‘‘rebalancing’’ mechanism, which typically results in either an extension of the concession
period, an increase in tariffs payable by users, or sometimes an increase in the number of
parking spaces managed by the concessionaire, depending on the circumstances. This
regulatory environment has proven to be stable and predictable since the implementation of
the concession system more than 50 years ago and in the past, we have been successful in
relying on such protective legislation to seek additional compensation. Additionally, the
municipalities granting concessions have an interest in the success of public car parks since they
are a source of income for the municipality and the operation of car parks satisfies a public
need.

**_Highly stable business with limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements_**
For the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, 83.9% of our Adjusted EBITDA was
generated by our off-street concessions business, which had a Weighted Average Remaining
Duration of approximately 25 years. Between January 1, 2016 and September 30, 2019, we
have achieved a consistently high Replacement Rate across the business of 121%, including a
Replacement Rate our off-street concessions of approximately 189%. Our off-street concessions
business also benefits from regulated tariffs linked to inflation. Accordingly, we benefit from a
high level of recurring business and long-term visibility of cash flows, and we believe the longterm nature of our portfolio is matched by few other infrastructure companies in Spain and
Portugal. The most significant contracts in the off-street portfolio are public concession
agreements, with none or limited rent payments, which is not the case of a typical lease
contract more common in other European countries.

For the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, 16.5% of our Adjusted EBITDA was
generated by our on-street concessions business. We have achieved a Replacement Rate of
approximately 73% between January 1, 2016 and September 30, 2019, with respect to our
on-street concessions business. In addition, we also won a number of our competitors’ contracts
and, in some instances, we have successfully renewed our on-street concessions business despite
our competitors submitting more competitively priced bids than us. We believe this is due to
our superior technical competence, including the implementation of state of the art revenue
collection technology, and our wealth of industry experience.

Despite the decrease in demand and volumes within our parking facilities that we experienced
during the prior economic downturn, we were able to mitigate some of the effects through
inflation-indexed price tariffs under the majority of our off-street and on-street concessions
business and off-street contract management agreements, as well as growth in our concession
portfolio and our implementation of cost management measures. The stability of our business
and the resilience of our Adjusted EBITDA during the economic downturn are illustrated in the

Our business model shares all the key features of infrastructure companies, such as long-term
cash flow visibility, resilient revenue generation, long-term concessions and a favorable and
stable regulatory environment with certain protections for the concessionaire in case of
regulatory or administrative change. However, unlike some other infrastructure companies
(including those operating toll roads), our car parks, once operational, require relatively low
levels of maintenance capital expenditure. Our limited maintenance capital expenditures are a
result of our scale and preventive maintenance measures and low operating intensity. Our
average maintenance capital expenditure during the years ended December 31, 2016 to 2018
was approximately e2.2 million per annum and mainly related to the requirements of our car
park contracts, including recurring maintenance works and repairs on our car park facilities to
ensure that they remain fully operational and compliant. As a result, we believe we are
well-positioned to benefit from returns on these investments. We expect to adjust our capital
expenditure plan to ensure that our technology systems are up-to-date with new technological
developments.

We benefit from attractive working capital dynamics with low levels of credit risk with respect
to our off-street concession business, since such revenues are collected from users when they
exit the car park. Our current business does not require significant investment in working
capital. For example, our off-street concessions business line generates negative working capital
because our revenues are generally collected when earned and our costs are paid according to
standard payment terms as agreed in each of our contracts. However, our on-street and
contract management businesses have higher working capital requirements as they are more
dependent on the payment terms from contracts with public bodies. In addition, our credit risk
with respect to our on-street concessions business is primarily with the municipalities rather
than private third parties. As a result of our low maintenance capital expenditures and working
capital requirements, we have achieved significant Free Cash Flow Conversion ratios of 63.9%
and 83.1% for the year ended December 31, 2018 and the twelve months ended September 30,
2019, respectively.

Any larger capital expenditures are primarily related to the expansion of our business,
including new acquisitions and grants of new contracts and concessions. We are constantly
securing new contracts and concessions as existing contracts and concessions expire. These are
based on our analysis of investment opportunities and are typically not linked to prior
commitments. Capital expenditures linked to the expansion of the business depend upon
specific requirements from newly awarded contracts. Additional capital expenditures may be
required in connection with the renewal of on-street contracts nearing their maturity date. Our
limited maintenance capital expenditure requirements are illustrated for the years ended
December 31, 2016, 2017 and 2018, and for the nine months ended September 30, 2019, by the

achievements. This over performance can also be attributed to the senior management team’s
ability to anticipate and embrace new trends and technology in the car park sector, which has
enabled us to be a pioneer in the deployment of efficient improvement programs and
user-friendly applications, such as electronic payment devices, license plate recognition systems
and mobile applications.
